As always, thanks to my co-authors @MatheusVXF and @ks_kulk, my alt @GuilleAngeris and other researchers including but not limited to @jason_of_cs, @theyisun, @pumatheuma, and @pgarimidi for answering my random questions / inquiries

In a world where even Google succumbs to pressure to run credible auctions, I believe that cryptocurrency can lead the way in mechanism design. Things like this auctions and other "cryptography for decentralized mechanism design" (@elaineshi) things are a light out of the tunnel https://t.co/Bg00US9b9X

What else can be done? Use ZK/FHE to
1. Increase the set of valuation distributions that can be used (FHE, in particular, allows for this, albeit in a strict model)
2. Model interdependent credible auctions

https://t.co/Ul8UXZefkj

In fact, @VitalikButerin's 'cost to deviate' calculations are precisely those which we use to compute the cost of the auctioneer (the proposer) deviating for censoring!

https://t.co/rVkYA6dea6 https://t.co/W6OrrNmVIY

What does this mean for MEV auctions?
1. Chains like Flashbots' SUAVE and @SkipProtocol can act as this clearing house for commitments (some are ZK) to ensure credibility in auctions
2. PBS can be made credible with this auction if consensus enforces the DRA + commitments

As such, perhaps having the commitments on a public blockchain changes the strategy space and allows for wider, fatter value distributions — this is indeed what we find! By forcing the commitments to be on a public blockchain, the auctioneer cannot deviate as much as in private

The insight of the original credible auction paper is that you need to model the interaction between bidders and auctioneers on a game tree (an extended form game) that includes the set of messages they are allowed to use and communicate w/ one another (almost like a UC proof)

Turns out, no! We construct a number of examples of DEX transactions in MEV auctions that need fatter tailed distributions in order to work (and we come up with some extreme cases of liquidations that cannot be handled by any independent private auction!) — can we do better?

When you assume the auctioneer and bidder communicate over a private channel, it turns out the strategy space of deviations from honest behavior is really large! As such, you can only handle valuation distributions that are "nice" and not "jumpy" (monotone hazard). Good enough?

Seems simple enough! But the hard part: how much collateral do you require bidders to post? That depends on their valuations for the item at hand and this is where it gets tricky — if the valuation distribution is really fat-tailed, then the collateral req'd will be >> bid (bad!)

Stage 1: Bidders post commitments to their bids as well as collateral
Stage 2: Bidders reveal their bids and if you don't reveal, your collateral is slashed/seized

Main idea: If the auctioneer cheats (e.g. injects a fake bid in a second price auction), they are then liquidated

Back to the paper: @MatheusVXF's first paper (w/ M. Weinberg) on getting around the credibility trilemma involves what is known as a deferred revelation auction (whose etymology is from Dütting, Gkatzelis, and @timroughgarden) which has two stages of commitment and revelation https://t.co/Di80LtvWL7

The two main questions that nerdsniped both of us were:
a. Can Flashbots-style MEV auctions be credible, incentive compatible, and decentralized?
b. Can PBS be made credible?

Surprisingly, it turns out that for private, independent valuations, you kill two birds with one stone!

Given that @MatheusVXF's paper was on strategies for PoS deviation (e.g. selling future blocks in the window before you're the proposer), I figured I'd try to learn about how commitments get  around the credibility trilemma (esp. since SGX/ZK alone doesn't get you around it) https://t.co/suGxqEzK6o

The focus then on trustless MEV auctions came in the form of @VitalikButerin's post on PBS and @bertcmiller's proposal to use SGX for private auctions. But even if auctions were private, it isn't at all clear that searchers + the auctioneer can't collude

https://t.co/aghJeZ3LCM

Before paper details, some backstory: Last year at @AcmSIGecom EC '22, @GuilleAngeris & I met @MatheusVXF, who spent time analyzing getting around the credibility trilemma with cryptographic commitments

My brain raced immediately to MEV being the ultimate user of such a system

Uniqueness results for auction types:
1st price: Truthful, Bounded
2nd price: Credible, Bounded
Clock: Truthful, Credible

Can we get around this? It turns out if you use cryptographic commitments (even simple ones like Pedersen) you can but with some major caveats https://t.co/WXtOw60GlZ

tl;dr: You can only get an auction that has 2 out of 3 of:
1. Truthful: Bidders bid their real value
2. Credible: Auctioneer incentivized to not place fake bids / deviate from honest strategy
3. Bounded Communication between bidders, auctioneer (no infinite back and forth)

Speaking of future work, a few open problems:
1. Can you have Seller (& credibility) + Buyer IC simultaneously?
2. How do you generalize to multiple dimensions?
3. Can you approximate optimal revenue, esp. w/ more complicated models of buyers that stay for longer amounts of time?
There is likely a lot hidden in this paper that will be useful for describing approximately revenue optimal MEV auctions and PBS — but that's for future work 😊

The answer is yes and these conditions are encoded in a particular matroid that relates the valuations of the users to the prices of the generalized GDA — we can get ex post incentive compatibility with the right choice of prices! https://t.co/DaVxZ0x0DE

One key thing to note is the set of initial prices a_i and decay function p(t) implicitly encode a prior distribution over users (akin to the private value distributions known in the Bayesian setting)

Q: Can we adjust them to reflect the interdep. valuations of the bidders?

The GDA, in a sense, can be viewed for these types of users as a sequential posting price auction, first studied by Chawla, @jasondhartline, et. al — these auctions have approximate revenue optimality guarantees in the Bayesian private independent values setting https://t.co/wk1ght51jK

One modeling assumption for GDAs is that all buyers have finite time preference — buyers who have perpetual utility will wait arbitrarily long for a GDAs to have price near zero; instead we consider ephemeral buyers who arrive randomly and are offered a take-it-or-leave it price

Now back to GDAs: In our paper, we utilize a different version of Roughgarden's conditions (from Chawla, 2014) and show that you can construct price decay functions and initial prices such that you meet these sufficient conditions (which are particular matroid conditions) https://t.co/Pj13AVCq2o

The first framework to establish this was from @Tim_Roughgarden, et. al which provided a notion of Myerson's Lemma (fundamental to proving IC) for interdependent auctions which gives sufficient conditions for ex post IC

https://t.co/haOJSdihOt

But it is likely by the LLN that the total amount of oil in the plot of land is better reflected by the *average* value of s[i] than the maximum, so the winner overvalues the land (winner's curse in signal form)

How do we get to incentive compatibility from signals?

The signals represent private information that each buyer is using that can be common to many of them; for instance, the ith buyer's signal could be, "I sampled for oil and found X liters of oil"

For instance, each bidder samples s[i] and the bidder with maximum s[i] wins https://t.co/KURgslXUEv

Interdependent auction values are much more difficult to model and analyze than private independent auctions. The first attempt at this was the classic paper of Milgrom & Weber which models a user's valuation v as a function of signals s from all agents https://t.co/UpOfsBDr48

Winner's curse is a phenomena where the winning bidder overpays & realizes a loss

e.g. buyers bid on buying a plot of land based on how much oil is in the land, the winning bidder is likely the person who got the highest overestimate of the amount of oil

https://t.co/ZX4MmkZEtS https://t.co/D47j7jztpX

However, GDAs involves what are known as *interdependent valuations*, in that the buyers' bids will change based on others' valuations. Two examples of this:

1. @ParisHilton.eth buying a BAYC causes others valuation to go up more than if Tarun.eth bought it
2. Winner's Curse

1st systematic analysis of NFT auction IC was from @jason_of_cs, @PGarimidi, et. al — showed that in the private, independent values (e.g. each buyer samples their value for an item independently from a distribution only they know) collusion resistance is effectively impossible

Before describing this, let's step back and understand incentive compatibility in more depth. An auction is IC when:
A. Sellers: don't increase revenue w/ fake bids or participating in the auction
B. Buyers: truthful strategies maximize their welfare (buyer's value - price)

Is the story over? 

No! It turns out that if you generalize the set of GDAs to include a larger set of functions (e.g. decaying functions that jump in an increasing manner) you can recover ex post IC by fitting the auction's price functions in a particular Bayesian manner

This attack demonstrates a lack of credibility (in the sense of @ShengwuLi's credibility trilemma, pictured) in exponential GDAs  — the mechanism isn't incentive compatible for the seller as she can gain excess revenue by deviating from an honest protocol  by adding "fake bids" https://t.co/hoSceri72n

One could view the auctioneer's deviation in two ways:
1. A form of adding "fake bids" to push up the minimum price (if user's values are interdependent, then they'll pay more due to the existence of other buyers)
2. A form of wash trading (especially if the auctioneer resells)

Using some simple math (and an appearance by the Lambert W function), we show that under some conditions the number of rounds to buy for the auctioneer to be profitable is often finite! 

Also show that demand curve's gradients control profitability in a pretty direct manner

The attack is pretty simple: The auctioneer buys the first r GDA auctions, pushing the minimum price up to a[r+1]*p(t)

If there is sufficient demand from buyers, then they have to buy at a higher price, reducing their welfare https://t.co/qkfcR4fafz

But @ks_kulk was undeterred and showed that this was indeed the case for the original GDA! He found explicit attacks against the blog's GDA and discovered an attack that a seller could use to extract more revenue from the auction if they know properties of buyer demand

When the OG @paradigm GDA blog post from @frankieislost, @danrobinson, @_Dave__White_, and @andy8052 came out, I assumed the auction would not be IC and/or optimal due to the lack of strategyproofness of "simple" dutch actions (see this intro from David Parkes) https://t.co/Wp3oMWKd8N

Such auctions are indirect mechanisms since the bidder only reveals their value indirectly (e.g. don't reveal type) and in a manner dependent on time (e.g. I buy auction 1 for a_1 * p(t) and auction k for a_k * p(t) to get the bundle {1, k} @ time t) — hard to analyze them fully https://t.co/ffvnXfvfU0

Why would you use such an auction? If you have a series of NFT auctions (e.g. an edition, a daily @nounsdao auction, etc.), you want to incentivize users to pick bundles (e.g. any subset of items to buy) without forcing all of the supply on the market (reducing auction revenue)

Quick recap: A gradual dutch auction (GDA) is a sequence of n auctions whose initial prices a_1 < ... < a_n are increasing but where the price of an auction decays as a_i * p(t) where p is non-increasing (e.g. p(t) = exp(-t) in the original paper)

https://t.co/B7UsmVtb1E

While @artgobblers isn't exactly my cup of tea, the novel NFT auction mechanism ford is cool from an auction theory perspective— but is it incentive compatible (IC) for both buyers and sellers?

tl;dr: It is *not* IC but can be modified to be IC!

@toghrulmaharram @llllvvuu @time_composer @0xCharanko @aeyakovenko Sort of; IIRC the worst case communication complexity scales as something like 1/(B-A)^k as B -> A so the queue size is relevant when B is only a small amount bigger than A
@toghrulmaharram @llllvvuu @time_composer @0xCharanko @aeyakovenko It won’t be if B/Q are small!

@toghrulmaharram @llllvvuu @time_composer @0xCharanko @aeyakovenko Quantifying that is important if you assume, e.g., the sequencers have a bandwidth limit of B and a maximum queue size of Q — is the constant less than a low degree polynomial of B, Q? If not that’s bad
@toghrulmaharram @llllvvuu @time_composer @0xCharanko @aeyakovenko Could be a very big constant though! That’s the point
@0xLuthor @llllvvuu @toghrulmaharram @aeyakovenko @dntse @sreeramkannan You are @sobylife’s alt
@toghrulmaharram @llllvvuu @time_composer @0xCharanko @aeyakovenko As well as the communication complexity for the end users (how many resubmit actions do they need to do?)
@toghrulmaharram @llllvvuu @time_composer @0xCharanko @aeyakovenko Yeah the point is quantifying that — a choice of fork choice rule changes that time scale (sometimes dramatically)

@toghrulmaharram @llllvvuu @time_composer @0xCharanko @aeyakovenko The idea being that “forced inclusion” can become “really slow eventual inclusion” which is acceptable only for some values of “really slow”

@toghrulmaharram @llllvvuu @time_composer @0xCharanko @aeyakovenko Just that there’s some rate limit to how fast you can resubmit txns and showing that your individual realized liveness time goes up at least some a minimum time
@llllvvuu @toghrulmaharram @time_composer @0xCharanko @aeyakovenko Yeah Tse/Sreeram’s impossibility result for checkpointing PoS chains in PoW has to have some analogue for rollups

@llllvvuu @toghrulmaharram @aeyakovenko It might be easier, though, to try to analyze this using a combination of the GHOST formulation as a 2D Markov chain mixed with the results from this paper of @dntse and @sreeramkannan https://t.co/uEWapZIM8T
@llllvvuu @toghrulmaharram @aeyakovenko See Theorem 9 here; you need an analogue for rollups imo https://t.co/qcu4ZU66mc

@llllvvuu @toghrulmaharram @aeyakovenko However, it’s far from clear that the results hold if you have “two timescales” of finality — you have two block trees/DAGs where one fork choice rule depends on its local state plus the other DAG (whose update time is slower) — your 2D iid Markov process becomes 4D correlated

@llllvvuu @toghrulmaharram @aeyakovenko Arguably there’s probably some work to be done on multiple time scale fork choice rules; the proof that GHOST / Snowman achieve probabilistic liveness work assume a single time scale point process whose mean is equal to the block arrival time generating new blocks

@0xcoli @nope_its_lily How do you decide what "very large borrow" is? That will change relative to liquidity / volatility externally. I think you need to have a more fine grained controller https://t.co/pqF8sYL8At

@gupta_kanv @nope_its_lily Yeah, it is undoubtedly something to be done but with a lot of safeguards:
1. Bounds on maximal movement over a particular time window ("LTV caps")
2. Smoothing the volatility measurement over many blocks (reduces volatility manipulation)
3. "bounded variation" of LTVs

@gupta_kanv @nope_its_lily People were liquidating in very weird ways (e.g. borrowing CRV from another lending protocol to liquidate and then close the lent position), so I actually think the amount of MEV was quite high if there was a dynamic LTV (but I don't have a back of the envelope estimate)

@gupta_kanv @nope_its_lily Worst case is insolvency, best case is reduction in collateral ratio

But the trade-off between the two is quite hard to deal with (especially under a shock event)

@nope_its_lily Not if you're griefed on every block; there's also a notion of a 'volatility manipulation attack' (akin to a price manipulation one) that can be cheaper depending on how you calculate volatility. Its not so simple tbh

@nope_its_lily 1. Volatility spikes externally
2. Know volatility increase will cause LTV to lower
3. Go borrow as much as possible right before the LTV changes via an MEV auction
4. Cause the protocol to have some bad debt ~(LTV(vol1) - LTV(vol2)) * collateral

akin to https://t.co/RaFxXWJyGS

@MattWy337 @0xngmi So the moral of the story here is that the OP’s desire for error bounds or tolerances depends on a) the model you use for the protocol b) how well you can estimate confidence intervals and c) how fast you can numerically compute these

@mewn21 @eigenlayer The additional service here is “managing order book incentive rewards” instead of needing a new token for that
@mewn21 @eigenlayer Think of it as a programmable staking derivative that adds in extra rules so that you (as a validator) can provide additional services
@mewn21 @eigenlayer Doing it here for a MM token means you start with SOL/ETH/base token revenue sharing and then migrate to a token once and/or if it makes sense

@mewn21 @eigenlayer Nope; eigenlayer is a contract where you deposit the base token (eth) which is pooled; the pool is staked and adds extra rules (e.g. you submit oracle updates in addition to blocks) and you are slashed if you mess up the rules *additional* to consensus (like oracles)
@mewn21 @eigenlayer Restake SOL/ETH, split rewards

@B_Chou @0xhopf @0xfoobar @nikete @mjlorig Yeah my point is that the CeFi exchanges barely tell you how their calculations work and/or why they work — there’s still the “trust me bro, I computed the funding right” aspect which isn’t in DeFi

@0xhopf @0xfoobar @nikete @mjlorig For CFMMs w/ monotonic payouts, there's an analogue of LVR that likely works (at least in no-arb) — but for discrete time, it is actually quite a bit harder to write out this trade-off (but this is a great math problem to work on if you like combinatorics! hmu if so)

@0xhopf @0xfoobar @nikete @mjlorig Also, figuring out how to measure the cost of keeping spot-perps tight vs. the max latency they deviate more than x bps would make it a lot easier to compare these designs

@0xhopf @0xfoobar @nikete @mjlorig I guess that's fair, although they still clamp to 0.05% arbitrarily — which sort of nullifies the "average funding rate of the interval"

But this is why a DeFi version of this (with code you can read, reason about, and stress test) would be superior

@0xfoobar @nikete @mjlorig I think the cap is an artifact of making the "interest rate spread between the assets" a constant — if it was floating (e.g. using a DeFi lender's pricing), you shouldn't need to do the clipping or capping

@0xfoobar @nikete @mjlorig For instance: why is there no momentum term in the calculation of the spread? Why is it strictly perp price - spot price at a fixed time? Intuitively, the proportional mechanism is more or less doing gradient descent on (perp price - spot price) — and we know Nesterov > stock GD

@0xfoobar @nikete @mjlorig e.g. you get Binance-level tight spreads but require a huge amount of OI there to keep the assets synchronized — but what if you had a more capital efficient mechanism? It likely wouldn't be a proportional controller like most perps today

@0xfoobar @nikete @mjlorig Yeah, there's sort of a 'cost vs. latency' trade-off (latency of spread between perp and spot vs. cost of liquidity / arbitrage to keep the perp and spot prices in line) — this has never been written down formally

There was a project from @bryanhpchiang that evinced the MPC aspects of perps — but I think you need to combine that with an understanding of how to price the funding rate as a standalone security to improve current mechanisms — current env is good for this exploration

Somehow, taking the dialectic (or really, 'multi-lectic') view of perps as simultaneously a control mechanism, an adversarial oracle, and a form of leverage probably will lead you to better mechanisms than the current ones (and will be much easier to implement credibly in DeFi)

View perps as a model-predictive-controller → the current mechanism is a low frequency proportional controller

View the funding rate as a security → pricing should have some dependence on the IR spread between the assets in the perp (but CEXs make it .. constant?!)

Feeling a little inspired about perp mechanism design after talking with @nikete and @mjlorig today — the amount of copy-pasta mechanism design (e.g. everyone does 8h funding payments because... Bitmex did it and it worked?) that could be improved is pretty massive
@Adi_Dommaraju @alexhevans @GuilleAngeris haha, I was told something similar (e.g. people replicate barriers but not forwards)

@Adi_Dommaraju yeah, I'm not 100% sure how to do a bounded liquidity version of a CFMM power perp — we (@alexhevans, @GuilleAngeris) proved something generic for the payoff, but nothing about the liquidity mgmt

https://t.co/Rl9MdXjCDO

@Adi_Dommaraju Everlasting options also sort of seem weirdly manipulable in that people can try to 'grief' you if they can manipulate the oracle to oscillate around the strike price (so your net financing cost grows as Ω(T) where T is the time you've held the asset

@Adi_Dommaraju I think power perps as a CFMM are a lot cleaner — you only have to think of one loss function (net loss due to arbitrage / rebalancing) vs. two (funding rate + convexity cost around the strike)
@Adi_Dommaraju Yeah, it is expensive (I think people don't have intuition for how to trade convexity - funding rate vs. perps where it is ~linear - funding rate)

Research done to a) improve how commitments guarantee transaction covenant enforcement that is cheaper than TradFi and b) to reduce capital/treasury mgmt costs will bear the fruit of a far cheaper and more efficient system

And is the most valuable applied research period (to me)

So I impart you, especially @transmissions11 who hates this optimism, to look forward to how mechanistic and technological changes to the frontier are on the horizon and with ingenuity and a little luck will make DeFi competitive with traditional finance in the next decade

This might seem incredibly hard, especially in light of the fact that the more centralized alternatives (Terra, FTX) attracted capital more easily —  but the mechanistic improvements we can make are *much* farther than those of the last cycle especially with regards to MEV

Having lived through Gox and Bitfinex, I understand how you might feel like d) alone (+ UX/adoption) is not sufficient to be hopeful for DeFi but we only compete with TradFi if we *really* focus on optimizing capital mgmt and use cryptographic superpowers to be cheap & seamless

I think the optimism we should have for DeFi stems from the fact that we have:
a) tons of data
b) ZK/FHE ready-ish for their first applications (not true last cycle!)
c) capital/parameter optimization exists and has foundational methodology
d) The worst confidence in CeFi ever

Instead, perhaps driven by the CEX dominance for new issuance in 2021, we as a community focused on copy-pastaing TradFi products and hoping that they worked “better because our blockchain was [higher TPS/lower fees/better programming model]”

We ignored 1) — DeFi surprises you!

But DeFi’s goal should be to use verifiable commitments in cryptography to ensure that 1) and 2) have *lower costs* for capital providers and users AND generate subsidies (tx fees or MEV) for the networks they reside on

We as a community haven’t focused on doing that since 2020

Lending is a lot harder — adverse selection cost goes from the spread (1-10 bps) to percentage points (interest rate curves aren’t dynamic yet!)

What lowers adverse selection cost?

1. Capital buffers
2. Privacy
3. Neutrality of counterparty

In TradFi, all 3 cost you something

Uniswap, in particular, has the magical luck of being a protocol that doesn’t need to deal with real leverage (only synthetic leverage via ranges) — so it turns capital efficiency calculations into direct protocol and mechanism optimizations *without* regards for cost of capital

Having protocols be able to contribute their own capital requires time (time to earn fees to add) and financing (borrowing/issuing debt against equity/tokens) — but sometimes you get magic like UniV3 where a mechanistic change *simulates* leverage from protocol provided capital

In traditional finance, the denominator can be split into:

capital available = capital from lenders / SPV / LPs + capital from the principal (yes, your GP commitment, Mr./Ms. underwater crypto VC)

Right now, DeFi protocols contribute 0 to the latter so LPs bear the capital cost

Simplified definition of capital efficiency:

max amt of capital used for risk bearing ops / amount of locked capital needed to support those operations

DeFi: denominator is larger than it is in TradFi due to permissionless/censorship resistance

What’s missing to close the gap?

Continuing to improve both decentralized lending and treasury management are the most important things that we need to avoid some of the abjectly abysmal and frankly almost criminally negligent off-chain risk management that we’ve seen in the last 6 months

If you look on-chain, Alameda paid back it’s DeFi loans way before it covered anything in CeFi (because they couldn’t say, “trust me bro, don’t liquidate me” to a smart contract) — if you can’t see how this is the future of avoiding calamities, I don’t know what to say

The beauty of DeFi is that you:
a) Are able to adjust loan-to-values publicly
b) Make liquidations competitive and algorithmically enforceable

Combined, these lead to no sweetheart deals like “locked FTT loans, only 5% interest” that never get liquidated even when in default

Even more embarrassing is the fact that most CeFi lenders didn’t do (as far I can tell) their own liquidations of collateral — they would simply send it to an OTC broker (like Alameda — who probably liquidated their own loans!) and hope things checked out 🫡

The fact that Voyager never liquidated FTT or SRM and that exchanges were sitting on so much GBTC and *still* didn’t decrease loan-to-values for their largest customers is insanely irresponsible risk management — and it is 100x easier to adjust this as a CeFi lender than in DeFi

The most amazing thing in the filings is how abysmal centralized lenders (incl. exchanges) were at 2 critical functions:
1. Dynamically setting loan-to-values
2. Liquidating bad loans

It’s embarrassing that @gauntletnetwork’s weekly DeFi governance proposals are faster than CeFi

@Autoparallel Why did I need to mention the other three? Yang-Mills helped abstract instantons (e.g. tunneling) to connection 1-forms, flatness there still has the benefits of the Einstein eqs, and Donaldson/Yau/Narasimhan show how isomorphism between moduli space <-> base spaces (space-time!)

@Autoparallel The last thing is a bit radical — start w/ the set of self dual connections and then try to figure out what space-times work (but Atiyah, Penrose, Hitchin, etc. figured out how to do it in some restricted cases)

@Autoparallel tl;dr:
1. Yang-Mills: "self-dual connections are important"
2. Einstein: flat connections are "easy" (G = 0!)
3. Donaldson: flat connections are complex of stable vector bundles
4. Penrose: Moduli spaces of instantons (self dual connections) give rise to space-time

tl;dr: Crypto rebalances cost distributions between creation and maintenance of networks — things like “CFMMs incentivize arbitrageurs to keep a fixed portfolio weight” express this — and MEV is a rebalancing mechanism

Not sure why people hope Claude Shannon can fix it for them!

In my opinion, it is better to focus on redistribution of revenue via cryptographic means than defenses because cryptography gives so few information theoretic guarantees for MEV (so you can’t bound min/max values extracted!) — so how can you defend against the unknown art?

Other extractive networks in history, such as Google’s ad auction, had o(n) creation cost and Θ(1) maintenance cost which put the burden on users as the network grew (bad in 2022 for new networks of *all* forms!)

There’s always a trade-off between creation and maintenance cost of a a network and the beauty of crypto is that the maintenance cost is 
Θ(creation cost) for a lot of DeFi — don’t pretend you can get rid of it with negative externalities that you can’t provably remove 🥶

Throwing the baby out with the bathwater is bad — some, perhaps a large %, of this arb actually generates fees and makes 1559 operate correctly! Arb drives volume which drives validators (for ETH where block rewards are weak) -> killing it is net bad for the network!

I think a lot of applications wouldn’t exist without stat arb (of some form — it is such a generic term..) and the idea that you can isolate the economics of consensus from interacting with the economics of its applications is a fictional cosplay of fair ordering advocates 🎭

While the sentiment is directionally correct it misses out on the fact that stat arb is essentially in markets for making no-arb “more real” — the trade off of availability when you move from PoW to PoS has direct economic costs but TANSTAAFL — creativity doesn’t reduce this 😱

@0xzuberg @aerafinance Guardians are paid/penalized based on how they improve/worsen the DAO's objective fn. The DAO chooses its objective fn via governance and deposits into a vault to rebalance it

3. Guardians rewarded if they improve the objective (slashed otherwise)

Hopefully you enjoy it! I view the paper as a sort of PhD thesis on DAO management and hopefully it has a lot of interesting history and motivation for how we chose to solve the treasury management problem (and its ties to capital efficiency)  

https://t.co/54c1efE9Zm https://t.co/CbsyQa3NgS

One problem is people suggesting treasury updates have no skin in the game — there's no tie to how well their suggestion matches a DAO's goals/KPIs/etc.

Aera takes inspiration from futarchy to incentivize community members to be graded on how well they optimize community goals https://t.co/cRobgJhn7H

In TradFi the main 'organic' demand for derivatives is institutions that need to hedge their treasury portfolios — DAOs are the analogue of that in DeFi and yet they basically purchase _zero_ derivatives (because governance makes asset management hard!)

DeFi _should_ solve this! https://t.co/dftb89v0gR

Matching supply (from DeFi protocols) and demand (from DAOs) is one of the biggest unsolved problems as it could lead to a feedback loop where:
1. DAOs buy options/derivatives
2. Liquidity increases
3. Options/derivs get cheaper
4. DAOs buy more derivatives

Why is this good?

DAO treasuries are the ultimate untapped resource in 2022 — there's $9B+ of capital that hasn't been able to optimize its utilization and 100s of DeFi protocols offering hedging services (options, perps, ...) that aren't utilized — can we match supply with demand efficiently? https://t.co/vP2G48Yeow

For some applications (e.g. treasury management) futarchy gets over its major hurdles by taking advantage of CFMMs, online optimization, and attribution methods (e.g. Shapley attribution) — but this is just the beginning

Imagine all DAO parameters being competed on via futarchy! https://t.co/aAMOKb2MHs

I've spent a lot of time trying to understand why futarchy didn't work (I'd recommend this @VitalikButerin's post from 2014 for an intro) and tried to figure out if we've learned enough from DeFi over the last 3 years to overcome those failures

https://t.co/r3ZAY5oqU9

The goal of Aera is to make it possible for decentralized, censorship resistant treasury management to make it possible for DAOs to hedge their portfolios according to their own KPIs, goals, and objectives while also seeding new protocols with liquidity in a positive sum manner https://t.co/I5rbpWQhb2

One funny thing about DAO governance is that it makes it hard to manage assets held by a collective (why vote to sell the asset you're voting with?) — but for many collectives, asset management is more than pure yield optimization

Can we do better with a return to futarchy?

tl;dr: PID controlled interest rates are really attractive right now (even @ezraklein wants them) — but you have to be careful when designing or using them and you have to be even more careful with your methodology for designing and optimizing the risk-reward for rates off-chain https://t.co/7VilbS2A27

4. Money markets that allow for the spread to be dynamically adjusted, such as @compoundfinance V3, can avoid such attacks provided that the spread responds to shocks in demand (which can come from an attacker)
5. On-chain elasticities are really important for protocol design!

3. So far, all rate changes in @AaveAave and @compoundfinance have been ad hoc at best (and in some cases bad for the protocol). Having constraints, like the ones in this paper, when designing + optimizing interest rate models is something we've been focused on @gauntletnetwork

But what does this say about interest rate curves in DeFi?
1. Designing on-chain dynamic rates is hard (probably why its not live in @eulerfinance yet)
2. Don't trust interest rates set without a well-defined model (because it might accidental create yield scraping arbs!)
We then provide a variety of ways to mitigate this, all of which are a lot more gas expensive than the naive PID controller and require far more tuning (e.g. dependence on demand/supply elasticities)

We construct formal conditions for when the attacker is profitable and show that these conditions depend on how you set the reserve factor γ (@AaveAave / @compoundfinance terminology) 

The reserve factor controls capital efficiency (it is the spread between borrow/lend rates) https://t.co/66DUFAt5nS

In the paper, we construct and mathematically analyze a strategy that is like JIT in that the attacker is able to raise interest rates and then take more of the yield than passive lenders within the pool, akin to how a JIT attacker takes fees away from purely passive LPs

One interesting fact about PID IR curves is that you can cause their interest rates to spike by increasing demand.. but what happens if you spike the rate but then remove your demand while keeping the rate high?

You get an analogue of a Uniswap V3 JIT attack — but for lending!

In spite of there being multiple PID controlled interest rates in DeFi (@reflexerfinance, @mars_protocol — @eulerfinance does not do reactive rates based on their GitHub), no one has analyzed capital efficiency (CE) against these protocols (people think PID is positive for CE!) https://t.co/uXXzsUUC70

Oh I also don't mean that these particular examples had misinformation (most of the misinformation is in the contract specifications / fees) — I was just illustrating that these are definitions that people don't agree on

Finally, don't forget to follow @mjlorig, who figured out how to Peter Carr-ify (RIP) a lot of the really cool results in the paper!

Also thanks to @_Dave__White_/@llllvvuu/@snarkyzk and others for writings that inspired us to get to a concrete solution to this problem

In a world where there are so many perps, it can be hard to figure out what makes sense for your needs or not and we hope this work gives you a stepping stone!
 https://t.co/u31yHmBSnw

So why is this useful?
1. No-arb limits used to check if the properties of a perpetual protocol match (approximately) what is claimed in the spec
2. Mapping seemingly complex perps to simpler, well-understood products like LETFs helps w/ adoption
3. Model-free-ness is cool!!

Finally, we looked at models with jumps (e.g. compound Poisson processes) and were able to show a (relatively) clean payoff that relies on a large deviation-like function  and knowledge of the jumps size measure https://t.co/qYTuybZotK

Using this result, we're able to show that @opyn_'s Squeeth is precisely a leveraged ETF with a discounting factor that looks like a variance swap and show that CFMMs without fees are super-replicated by perps (so you'd rather be long the perp than a CFMM LP!) https://t.co/pRQRuZ32EY

This gets to the meat of Q2; we were inspired by misinformation about maintenance margin for different power perpetuals which comes from misunderstanding this discounting process

We show that a discount rate k exists s.t. F_t receives a kφ(S_t) for k < 1 but w/o collateral (!!) https://t.co/6tz63a2QOD

Another thing people look for in quant finance is an understanding of margin requirements (e.g. perp requires the long side to "pay" a deposit of φ(S_0))

Can we find a method that adjusts the payoff so that the long side doesn't need to put up collateral (at least in no-arb)? https://t.co/BGQpRxHDtQ

Using this result we then show that a long position in a paper is exactly equivalent to a long variance swap (VS) position _without_ an extra premium for volatility

VS tend to lose money b/c of the diff. between implied/realized vol — not true for perps!

https://t.co/Gfkwb5al6e

One other beautiful component of this replication formula is that it doesn't require a particular model (e.g GBM in B-S) to compute a payoff! This type of 'model-freeness' is one of the key benefits of perps in that users can trade them without precise parametrized models https://t.co/HhDCissevt

The first term in the replication is a 'convexity correction' for the convexity of the payoff φ while the second term is a 'tracking term' that adjusts the risk-free rate

Colloquially this says: longs are short payoff vol and FX vol whereas shorts are short φ(S_t) in no-arb

The excess payment term, F_t, is the funding rate and we can ask, "what should F_t be under no-arbitrage?" It turns out that we can write this precisely in terms of the payoff φ, which is Theorem 2 of the paper https://t.co/fm3xIAMyll

Q1: What is the funding rate process?

Given a price process S_t that is an Ito diffusion and a payoff function φ, a perp is something where the longs pay the short φ(S_0) + F_t and the shorts pay the longs φ(S_t) (with the longs having the option to exercise at any t)

We'll break down the points of the paper as answers to 3 questions:

1. What is the funding rate process?
2. Can we remove/lower collateral requirements?
3. What happens to funding rates when we have a jump diffusion / shock events? https://t.co/cgmTM6DHx7

Perps, despite being the most used financial product w/in the crypto sphere, have perhaps the highest amount of misinformation about their performance characteristics and financial replication properties (probably b/c people want to differentiate their product w/o full analysis!) https://t.co/jYFTmGyGd3

tl;dr: By redistributing MEV (e.g. via @eigenlayer + PBS) one can avoid bad economic equilibria in PoS — so much that you can safely have deflationary inflation schedules! This shows that there can be positive externalities to MEV when it comes to system design

cc @sreeramkannan

We then verified this with agent-based simulations and showed that even Bitcoin-like deflationary schedules can work provided that α is large enough (this is literally the @ultrasoundmoney meme!)

[y-axis is % staked, x is α] https://t.co/Kci9Zeocdh

We show the following results:

1. If R(k)/ε(k) is sufficiently large, then we avoid the 0% staked equilibrium
2. As α increases, we make the 0% staked equilibrium less likely
3. You can reduce R/ε for the same security by increasing α

Block subsidies can go down! https://t.co/HHUhlqBmTR

We use a simple autoregressive model that adds this component to the staking yield γˢ — unlike 2019, this paper now has feedback where the staking yield at time k+1 responds to the lending yield at time k — time to use optimal control!

Note: ε is burned tokens (EIP-1559) https://t.co/ZmcF2T2KDo

What is this model?

When @GauntletNetwork monitored the stETH/ETH deviation from par event on @Aave, I noticed that MEV revenue from liquidations was strongly positively correlated w/ utilization (and hence interest rate)

Model distributes α% of liquidation revenue to stakers https://t.co/cjUgVwIh1j

MEV redistribution provides more income to stakers — is it enough to reduce the likelihood that they migrate their assets from staked to lent?

To model this, we consider a simple model for redistribution based on MEV for on-chain lending protocols (which is mainly liquidations)

How do we quantify PoS economic security?

In 2019, I showed that unless PoS networks inflate sufficiently fast (exponentially), the total quantity staked can drop dramatically because rational validators reallocate their token to lending protocols

https://t.co/9oDHiIsFrb

In this paper, we look at what happens if such a mechanism were implemented — do we improve PoS economic security?  Does it get worse?

Surprising: It improves security *dramatically* in that you can have far lower block rewards (1st time the @ultrasoundmoney meme is justified!)

Why would a validator agree to this & make off-chain agreements (OCAs) to avoid paying x%?

1. PBS makes this expensive (see @VitalikButerin’s heuristic analysis)
2. Restaking (@eigenlayer) enforce redistribution while reducing variance for validators

https://t.co/rVkYA6dea6

What is MEV redistribution (also called MEV smoothing)?

💡: MEV profits split w/ x% go to all stakers and 100-x% to the validator themselves

Impossible to do in PoW, possible to do in PoS via Proposer-Builder Separation (see @ObadiaAlex/@taarushv's post) https://t.co/VmS3dqfuDw

🚨New Paper Alert🚨

There have been a number of proposals for sharing MEV revenue between particular block producers and the rest of the (staked) network. But is it safe?

@ks_kulk and I show there can be *positive externalities* from MEV redistribution!

https://t.co/yNKHGDeFwG

@jeffburdges @Tim_Roughgarden Those bounds are weak enough to make it hard to totally know the entire distribution beyond some error but also strong enough that the network doesn't sample the point mass distribution because it didn't adjust to players joining/leaving

@jeffburdges @Tim_Roughgarden This is the thing I think you're missing: adaptive adversaries in these papers are trying to guess the _instances_ drawn from a _fixed distribution_ of _fixed entropy_ — PoW instead draws from an unknown distribution but you have weak bounds on its entropy via difficulty

@jeffburdges @Tim_Roughgarden I'll say it again: there is NO difficulty adjustment for PoS because the distribution is known and public at all times (the hash power distribution is NOT — only an approximation!)
@jeffburdges @Tim_Roughgarden .. maybe you can emulate this property (hence why I brought up couplings and stochastic dominance type things before)

@jeffburdges @Tim_Roughgarden PoW adjustments don't work! In PoW _no one participant_ knows the entire hash power distribution — in PoS everyone knows the entire distribution to verify sampling. If you had a ZK program that did some non-trivial sampling algorithm that you could only verify the result of..

@jeffburdges @Tim_Roughgarden All of these things are "is it unpredictable CONDITIONAL on a fixed stake distribution" — difficulty adjustment means "I am unpredictable because my stake distribution is varying" — much higher entropy and harder to grind

@jeffburdges @Tim_Roughgarden The adaptive adversaries in Fantomette don't measure any long term correlations w/in sampling, unlike difficulty adjustment which has long-range data in it to ensure that KL(hashpower(t), hashpower(t+k)) doesn't diverge too much https://t.co/e0bb71ooIa

@jeffburdges @Tim_Roughgarden But if we didn't need the "boring" Markov sampling of the stake distribution, we could do something more interesting that preserves long term expected reward while trading off variance

@jeffburdges @Tim_Roughgarden This is why understanding adaptivity carefully is important — its a sense in which you don't know the entropy of the underlying distribution beyond some limit (e.g. TV(p, p') or KL(p, p') > eps) — but its coarse (only defined in terms of the support of the staking dist

@jeffburdges @Tim_Roughgarden The analogue for difficulty adjustment would be, "we are sampling P(stake_dist) where P is a random operator that you can't observe until after and P ensures that public estimates s for stake_dist have dist_TV(s, stake_dist) > epsilon"

@jeffburdges @Tim_Roughgarden Sure but this _still_ is not true in PoS where there is even more data center certainly for far too many coins (equinix going down probably kills a few L1s)

Difficulty adjustment is so underrated and PoS needs an analogue

@jeffburdges @Tim_Roughgarden I think the one coherent threat model is this adaptivity type of constraint — you have uncertainty about the distribution you're sampling that you can't remove which makes it harder to manipulate by adding capital immediately
@jeffburdges @Tim_Roughgarden Chinese miners moving to Texas proved that one government might seize while another gives you basically free power and tax incentives

@jeffburdges @Tim_Roughgarden But you can just move to a new jurisdiction and buy new hardware; with stake, you’re screwed if you lose your keys / “restart” cost is high unless the network is actually low Gini (and none are now)

@jeffburdges @Tim_Roughgarden The sampling mechanism in crypto hasn’t been improved… ever. We still sample a pretty boring Markov Chain; but perhaps being able to do the sampling as a private computation will open up the space for better sampling techniques than pure Markov

@jeffburdges @Tim_Roughgarden But I think there will be either cryptographic or statistical ways to emulate PoW’s distributional uncertainty; the latter seems more tractable but harder to design (do we sample a random coupling of the stake distribution to it self that preserves marginals or expected reward?)

@_jamiis No, the beacon chain is not SSLE unfortunately; the stake distribution and the computation are public; SSLE requires some FHE (but not a computationally intractable amount) 

adaptivity can be partially recovered if you could sample from the stake dist without it being public

*that

TCS people don’t care about ever defining the probability space correctly or in any generality so they “only” know incomplete probability spaces and hence run into these interesting and surprising counterexamples a lot

The sort of problem with assuming completeness or Polish spaces is that you conveniently ignore the fact that there are sometimes natural generative processes that weakly converge for finite n but don’t strongly converge in the limit

Probabilists often exclude these things when constructing probability spaces so they don’t have an ability to realize thst such examples say something about prob. distributions over instances of algorithms with dynamic processes (which could lead to CDFs with point masses @ ♾

One complement that I’ll give theoretical CS people over probabilists is that TCS people are really good at coming up with counterexamples that involve randomized algorithms with point masses at infinity (e.g. a CDF never reaches 1 in finite time)

But eventually, @ks_kulk and I spent 8 mos stomached the forest of non-convexity and brute forced an admittedly ugly way to get the bounds and results above (with some help from @theo_diamandis) — but @GuilleAngeris thinks we can convexify things with some luck 🍀🫰🏾

First, we tried to map this to a convex problem and information theory (privacy-utility trade-offs) to try to generalize to “all” types of MEV — but this turned out to be hard; we got pretty poor minimax bounds: https://t.co/X5rh7qBgrV

How did we get to these results?

After I wrote our last yr paper on differential privacy with @GuilleAngeris and @alexhevans, it became clear that there’s an equilibrium between MEV & privacy in DeFi: 

max amount extractable via MEV = cost user has to pay to miner for privacy

So why is this interesting?

1. MEV isn’t always bad! Paradoxes teach us that IRL equilibria aren’t always worst 
2. Privacy & MEV are intimately related; private DeFi needs to be built wrt these of results
3. Formalizing MEV → best way to make MEV auctions more efficient/fair

Is this really true in any generic sense or did we just find one counterexample? 

We justify this claim that sandwichers can be *good* for routing quality by showing that the Price of Anarchy, regardless of network graph, is *constant* provided there’s enough liquidity https://t.co/CnjsicrtN9

Classic Braess paradox has users go from splitting their traffic between A→C→B and A→D→B to routing all of their traffic A→C→D→B when C→D is turned on

Here, we have a sandwicher on C→D actually cause traffic to redistribute — better welfare for everyone! https://t.co/bd2WzG8EyB

On the other hand, consider the Braess network where we have four tokens A, B, C, D and 5 CFMMs between them; we show that when (C, D) is sandwiched, you can get *more* output tokens (even though the small % of users who cross (C, D) get worse behavior) https://t.co/2tXaI0VHon

We show that you can map this problem to a potential game (see @Tim_Roughgarden’s Selfish Routing papers) and numerically, you can see that users get worse output (y-axis) as they trade more on the edge w/ a sandwicher https://t.co/3CFF5W4oRz

2nd result: We provide 2 examples of networks of CFMMs, one which sandwiching *reduces* user welfare (reduces their output tokens) and the other that *improves* welfare

First example is a network w/ two CFMMs between tokens A and B https://t.co/lpOKUJepA5

Prophet inequalities are likely the key to generalizing ‘traffic congestion’ results to non-CFMMs. Why are non-CFMMs hard? They’re extremely non-local: it is possible that some reorderings of liquidations and trades cause no liquidation cascades whereas others jump to zero https://t.co/cF42T8h8pq

We call the ratio between the worst-case and average-case PNL the *cost of feudalism• (it is the worst-case cost that users pay the serfs [searchers] to get access to a block) — it turns out that this type of ratio sort-of exists in AGT under the name `prophet inequalities’ https://t.co/Bqrgux9P5S

Using these bounds, we show the first surprising result: the worst-case sandwich profit is often only O(log n) times worse than the average-case sandwich — this suggests that the compounding of sandwich attacks is relatively limited (even if the whole block is sandwich attacks) https://t.co/ohN8sU0oNb

Estimates provide heuristics for wallets/protocol designers to adjust curvature to reduce sandwicher PNL!

These calculations show how much sandwiches compound (measurement of knapsack difficulty) — useful for improving fees (e.g. params in @VitalikButerin’s Multidim. EIP-1559)

Slippage limits are defined by the *difference* of convex functions so the problem gets a bit hairier than @GuilleAngeris would normally like; given this definition we’re able to get bounds on sandwich profitability strictly using curvature: https://t.co/ngh1a0eQuU

Previous work defn’d sandwiching for Uniswap and Balancer — we generalize this to arbitrary CFMMs (incl. bounded support ones like Uniswap V3) by using CFMM curvature (= price impact / unit of liquidity) & expanding the language for describing trades to include a slippage limit https://t.co/uayw6hOhKa

Sandwiches are by and large the most popular form of MEV (c.f. Flashbots Explore)

But how do we analyze sandwiches in a CFMM agnostic manner?

First, we need to reason about how reserves (= liquidity) changes as a function of trade size and slippage limit and their price impacts https://t.co/smrKSxxBE7

How could sandwiches *help* with routing? Don’t they always rob the user being sandwiched??

Yes but they encourage other users to avoid trading across a CFMM edge in a network, smoothing congestion (an inverse Braess paradox!l)

First take a step back — what *are* sandwiches? https://t.co/M4iSyZ69UD

tl;dr: Answers are a lil’ paradoxical

1. Sandwiches are ‘local’ ➡️ worst case price that a user gets vs. average case price by received by a user is O(log n)

2. Sandwiches can *help* w/ routing (e.g. 1inch/Match) by making users avoid bad routes (and this holds asymptotically) https://t.co/ExbhOWwwHU
Goal of this work is to answer the following two questions about  the impact of sandwich attacks on reordering and routing: https://t.co/fm6Eco74SP

Prior work on MEV has focused on:
1. Fair ordering
2. Formal verification to estimate MEV profit
3. Single sandwiches on Uniswap
4. Empirical data
But so far, no one has talked about the theoretical costs to the entire network from MEV

This paper solves this (at least for CFMMs)

⏰⏰⏰ New Paper Alert ⚠️⚠️⚠️
MEV is always bad for users… right?

Not always! @ks_kulk, @theo_diamandis, & I formalize the loss from sandwich attacks and show that sandwichers act as decentralized highway traffic controllers & *improve* network welfare 

https://t.co/UmKbBhL2FM https://t.co/OCu5P3Sn2g

In other words, different liveness levels (e.g. bounded liveness w.h.p. vs. partial synchrony and unbounded liveness constants) correspond to different counterparty risk tolerance levels (and the court system has unbounded time enforcement — c.f. Epstein and Maxwell!)

But just like distributed systems that are “eventually” consistent versus “consistent in a bounded time” have different financial risk properties, so too does “eventual” probabilistic enforcement (CeFi/courts) versus “bounded time enforcement” (DeFi)

Arguably, the main difference between CeFi and DeFi counterparty risk is not that it’s *eventually* transparent (when a counterparty blows up all of your private docs are public in court) but that your agreements are actually enforceable without needing governments’ helping hand

Conclusions: MPC block reward distribution can be game theoretically secure (sick work, @_ignatieff!) https://t.co/e4ZoNdBgXd
Here's what the MPC payments look like (this is actually useful for MPC protocols like @entropydotxyz IMO) https://t.co/8sH0IRhMBX
Here's the MPC state machine (e.g. information structure) whose leaf nodes = utilities / payments made to ensure delta-security https://t.co/RJ2VzZ4tXR

When is this useful? MPC! You need to figure out how to distribute a block reward to different MPC participants (e.g. if you're @entropydotxyz) — but there the payments depend on how much security you want (3 models) https://t.co/zjpyO1dpFp

For this scenario, we can explicitly use Gaussian elimination to find the correct payments that the players need to make to ensure they have delta-Game theoretic security (e.g. if I cheat, I lose at least $delta) https://t.co/ptW3bY5YxC
Here's the info structure (e.g. payments under cheating vs. honest behavior) https://t.co/UdVKr7zLcg
Here's an example of the payment scheme between the different cats (the utility matrix is at the bottom U) https://t.co/Alc5UbJoAZ

One way of ensuring a "zero sum" type of condition is the budget balance condition (e.g. you can't have 'inflation' in this game) — btw this is also similar to the tx fee condition that @Tim_Roughgarden had in his axiomatic fees for blockchains paper from SBC '20 https://t.co/mNrnmfA6Jm

We turn the payment scheme problem ("given an information structure, is there a payment scheme that is an equilibrium for both players?) into a linear algebra problem — actually an LP! https://t.co/fQsn7TqcIt

One should really think of this as a generalization of Lightning or Interledger — what is the set of possible payment schemes on an information structure (e.g. a programming language for describing utilities for the players) https://t.co/TWkH9l0Es5

Another heap... of cats — now we map the set of games played to confirm a payment via an interaction tree (alternating RB tree of player actions); using quasi-linear utilities of the players, we construct how much the payment is after k rounds of play https://t.co/CE0TlBnBk4

Setting up the problem: What's the most general payment game? 

1. Turns out it is an LP (hence P-completeness) 
2. There exists some payment scheme for every public function (no size guarantees)
3. Lower bound on payment price (this seems like a duality gap...) https://t.co/5zUHFX1KAB
Conclusions: https://t.co/kYHIFnB4Q1
Next, defines the gradients as the marginal prices and now constructs no-arb conditions https://t.co/6TvVSLYak5

Best quote of the talk from @GuilleAngeris: "actually, solving a problem on the extend reals because negative infinity is when you would rather do anything else, like jump off a bridge, than trade this token" https://t.co/oihYKMAVKX

Next he defines the matrix A which maps local token indices (e.g. token index at CFMM i) to global index — mainly so that you can write the flow as a simple linear function of the portfolio weights https://t.co/aEJfXpNlmL
Now defining the network of CFMMs and constructing the graph as well as the per CFMM parameters (reserves, trading fn, fee, reserves) https://t.co/1BjuV6LoWl
Why do we need routing? Why not just provide liquidity for A->B for all pairs A->B (explaining capital efficiency, effectively) https://t.co/1VgdwnusdV
Describing why the trading function is concave (or really,  minimal concave equivalent trading function — see Improved Price Oracles, Angeris and Chitra, 2020 appendix) https://t.co/np4p72G3nq
Next we define the generic portfolio, trading function, and the epigraph (not constant!) condition https://t.co/SuIKz1V7z2
Slides start by explaining CFMMs as a binary predicate https://t.co/JhlycayNwQ

Next up is @GuilleAngeris presenting our paper w/ @alexhevans and Stephen Boyd — Guille starts by saying "everyone in this room probably knows about optimal routing but probably not CFMMs"

He also blames me for any typos in the slides, lmao https://t.co/aRJo9of9J2

Assume Alice has a bisection oracle on this heap structure (she can figure out how to throw out half the tree each point)

—> Construct branching process
—> Get recursion for expected revenue
—> Maximize rev and can get >100% improvement (BAD — put in X stake, I get 2X rewards) https://t.co/Zq1c4lUM2h

Now we can try to construct strategies as a function of finding a maximal "weight" (she constructs a r.v. that scores paths in the tree from aggregating success probabilities) — 1-lookahead strategy (depth 1 heap) gives you 6-10% improvement in revenue — can we squeeze more?

Strategic Mining: Distributing your stake over multiple accounts — min property creates a heap — this heap over Sybil's can basically be analyzed and is a way for Alice to hide her score https://t.co/yO7hrLpwKD

Also bad: instead of grinding the block hashes you grind the VRF — which is possible (but more expensive); instead, use cryptographic self-selection

Note that (Micali, et. al, 2019) proved it isn't _fair_ in that x% stake always has a strategy that can earn (x+eps)% https://t.co/LAwiksDzUM

But: This model of PoS is vulnerable to block grinding (e.g. just block hashes grind until you satisfy the minimum condition in); strawman 2 (instead of a block hash, hash the previous random string drawn from the VRF)

Bad: turns PoS into PoW https://t.co/FLlnjKIwA5
First, he's motivating his construction / "ideal functionality" description of PoS via a VRF + common random reference string + scoring function https://t.co/KVR47XljMB

@mewn21 @WhosDaveStanton @taroon_5 ... not too periodic — monodromy can do that for you (Z_m symmetry = m-fold symmetry — I can rotate the field 360º, 720º, ..., 360*mº times and not change the physics — but not 360*(m+1)º [which is = 360º in m-fold])

@mewn21 @WhosDaveStanton Okay, lemme try to @taroon_5 it:
1. Symmetries give rise to conserved quantities (e.g. if I rotate the world and the physics doesn't chg. angular momentum is conserved)
2. Periodic symmetry = I can rotate by 360º, 720º, ..., 360nº, ..
3. Periodic symmetries in quantum fields..

@mewn21 The inspiration is this classical paper from Vafa about turning periodic modes in a field (Z-action) into monodromy modes (Z_m-action) which is used to model cosmic microwave background inflation in the early universe https://t.co/1PpdGBx0W5

@samlafer Which means the yield from a competing form of yield (e.g. on-chain lending) directly competes w/o any extra FX risk (unlike PoW)

@samlafer That's the 2nd order impact; the first paper really just focuses on lending vs. staking yields; remember the PoW yield is denominated in coin (Bitcoin) but the input costs are in fiat (energy); for PoS, yield and input costs are the _same_ (which is explained in the slides)

@samlafer PoW has coin distribution and resource (hash power) distribution separate and not instantly correlated UNLESS you have liquid hash power derivatives to hedge coin distribution deltas — PoS is the opposite (so lending competes _directly_)

@0x_Broke_Boi @anon75374998 @hasufl DECO as an interest rate oracle? I think the main issue is that most on-chain lenders use on-chain data (such as capital utilization rates) to deterministically compute an interest rate; even if I blind the utilization, I still have to publicly reveal the rate -> side channel
@anon75374998 @hasufl Likely impossible unless you price on a different metric than utilization

@anon75374998 @hasufl The solvency piece seems relatively amenable to a ZKP; the place where I see more issues is the interest rate curve, especially if it's a dynamic curve that adjusts based on utilization and dUtilization/dt (similar side channel privacy loss as CFMMs)
@anon75374998 @hasufl You could have a ZK proof of solvency without revealing identity and/or position size (not saying optimal though)
@ittaia @cronokirby *perfectly random
@ittaia @cronokirby But I agree that things like this + FLAX are the way to implement designs that approach the info theory lower bound for the minimal privacy-utility trade off
@kvny2046 @hasufl @_weidai . @_weidai's paper is very cool

@cronokirby But I agree that it might be too weak of a formalism in that it gives very loose bounds — but unlike ZK/MPC, it does provide some guidance into which operations/functions are "better blinded" than others if some of the outputs are necessarily public

@cronokirby It is agnostic to how much compute you have to do to reverse the encryption, it is more about "what is the minimax bound for how many bits of entropy about the _instance_ of x that I observe can I extract?" This good enough to trade on / for MEV

@cronokirby Not necessarily all, it depends on the transition functions X -> S, S -> Y; but my point is that a ZK version of, say, a CFMM, constructs X -> S in a particular way that can leak information about X depending on the instance of x chosen and the particular circuit used
@DCbuild3r Needs fewer typos first 😅

@cronokirby No, they're phrased strictly in terms of the mutual information I(Y; X) of the public data Y given a process you observe X -> S -> Y, where X -> S is the private calculation and X is the private data

@cronokirby In fact, information theoretic lower bounds for public revelation but private computation lower bounds exist (and ZK does not get around this on its own!) See John Duchi, ch 6 https://t.co/iUXzgKUjeR

@cronokirby ZK isn't a panacea on its own when your public outputs have some correlation to your private inputs, that's why we wrote this paper for CFMMs (maybe there's a non CFMM that is still deterministic that works) https://t.co/ictjdaSiOf

@cronokirby Cryptographic tools have two problems:
1. Setup (in the searcher + user + validator case)
2. You _always_ need a public price/rate/...
3. MPC still leaks information (e.g. latencies) in each communication round to relayers — non-zero information re: trading there
@cronokirby It is a combination of how people do it in federated learning + information theory

@0xfuturistic @The3D_ @rleshner @samkazemian Intuition for why PID is bad: PID controllers have a characteristic time constant t (e.g. d for EIP-1559); if I can temporarily increase borrow for t/2 time & cause IR to jump by (1+r) while I also supply for t units of time, other borrowers effectively pay me unless high spread

@llllvvuu @jonwu_ @opyn_ @GuilleAngeris I'd basically end by saying that there's likely some theory for why the constraints of blockchains (finite space, transaction fees, competition) seem to preference certain mechanisms that are uneconomical in normal finance — convexity/probability do a different dance

@llllvvuu @jonwu_ @opyn_ While @GuilleAngeris might say this is "obvious" because anything non-convex isn't really solvable on-chain by Jump, et. al let alone 🦧🦧, there's some curious structure to the protocols that end up having longevity outside of pure liquidity advantages

@llllvvuu @jonwu_ @opyn_ But yet the convex analytic properties seem to seep deeply into the probabilistic part of these instruments — almost as if the temporal freedom is provided by guarantees/bounds on gradients/hessians (or their non-smooth analogues) in some mysterious way to market participants
@llllvvuu @jonwu_ @opyn_ It feels more fundamental than just *hey some part of the code is just convex analysis* yet the things that seem to work ascribe to that mantra and .., work

@llllvvuu @jonwu_ @opyn_ This concept of 'weak perpetual' is kind of interesting; its sort of the difference between 'almost sure' and 'convergence in probability' but I am still not sure how to precisely define it — if staking is 'strongly' perpetual, then on-chain derivs have weird temporal properties
@llllvvuu @jonwu_ @opyn_ *have

@llllvvuu @jonwu_ @opyn_ The interesting thing is that quantitative finance (both practitioners and theorists) has mainly focused on finite duration / weakly perpetual instruments... but somehow nothing in DeFi looks like this which means its an open field

@llllvvuu @jonwu_ Had a fun convo w/ some former tradfi options traders about this — is there a way to go 1-1 between options spreads and funding rates for a perp? Probably not bijective but... probably a k-1 map for k small..

@llllvvuu @jonwu_ Forward curves in crypto are odd because the curves implied by derivatives ("are perps in contango?") are different than those implied by rates — once options are actually liquid enough, we could probably correct but not yet imo

@llllvvuu @jonwu_ Covering interest rate parity is a lot more complicated here; to @jonwu_'s point, opportunity cost > "risk-free" rate in crypto, but the opportunity cost has a weird thing where you need to weight by collateral risk (which sort of ends up being in the noise)

@quentinc137 stETH (the ERC20 on ETH1) needs to be redeemed for ETH2 assets once transfers are enabled, but if there's a liquidity crunch or the price of stETH : ETH isn't near 1, then there's a large arbitrage between ETH1 and ETH2 (we can't really treat them as the same at time of merge)
🔥 take: The deleveraging of stETH/ETH is actually a good thing to happen significantly before the merge occurs (imagine if the transactions of the last few days happened an hour before the merge!)

@bookdepth Its definitely going to be interesting to fit even simple models around this event to see how the market is pricing:
a) opportunity cost 
b) variance in the time to merge

Question to me is how much does the latter impact the merge’s success, especially if mkt is releveraged

@craigjson You effectively always have to retrain on these events; in a lot of ways you're always fitting E[f(X) | Y > a] where X is a price/quantity and Y is some RV you condition on (e.g. depegging)
@craigjson Final recommendations are still sanity checked by humans, but the exploration process of the parameter landscape is automated (akin to AI hyperparameter optimization)

@ThogardPvP Definitely; we spend a *lot* of time on probabilistic slippage and impact models and adjust them to events that cause large deviations from predictions (which is easier here than in CeFi trading since the data is more available)

@0xShitTrader Crypto is cool because transparency allows you to have models that are in between HFT and ad auctions — you can try to do causal inference because you actually have the event data of all participants (unlike trading)

@0xShitTrader And then try to incorporate that into models of liquidator behavior and look if that matches a hypothesis test against your set of realized liquidations; the art comes in computing the confidence interval for the hypothesis test but this is strictly better than yolo!

But we’re always working on improving this (and other risk-related) objective function, monitoring of on and off chain txns, and the optimization algorithms for minimizing it — we’ll have a blog post soon™️ on how we do this search over models and parameters fully autonomously 🤖

To search over the space of models that match the real data that you condition on (e.g. fitting models conditional on realized peg deviation between a% and b%), @priorupdates did hyperparameter optimization using the objective function detailed in previous blog and forum posts

Gauntlet’s @watsonfu_ has been taking a look at the depegging event data and fit various counterfactual models for when there are liquidation cascades

You see a sharp phase transition and some jump to zero behavior, but these points are sensitive to how you condition your model https://t.co/tB2ketbiZh

One thing I want to add about this is that depegging events (even perceived ones, for assets that are meant to be bounded distance from each other and correlated) can have subtle phenomena to model and you need real events (like the last week’s) to find the phase transitions 🧪

@CometShock @0xngmi Yeah, so hopefully after the market calms down a bit, it’ll be possible to measure the risk premia term more carefully than we have in the past (where it was basically assumed to be 0)
@NickelJ3 @0xngmi Yeah that’s fair
@_vshapovalov @0xngmi I agree there’s an arbitrage when you’re far from the realization/liquidity event though

@_vshapovalov @0xngmi Right, but staking implies that market participants’ private valuations are all > 1 (adding the staking yield) yet the market price is <= 1 — which upon nearing the merge should cause the market price to jump above 1 once the timing of the liquidity event of the merge is known
@CometShock @0xngmi The problem is also Var[time_to_merge] > 0 (so you don’t a priori know your opportunity cost for minting stETH) and liquidity risk premia you implicitly price in

@_vshapovalov @0xngmi Sort of; it could also be k:1 for k > 1 if the total implied yield from Lido is higher than all current eth opportunity yields. There’s also an extra implied risk term for pricing the fact that Var[time_to_merge] > 0 which counters this (part of the risk premia)

@0xngmi Well to Spreek’s point, there’s no a priori reason it needs to be 1:1 (e.g. the discounted ETH2 yield might be worth more than any opportunity you can do right now) — but data from this event will effectively let us measure if the market implies that under liquidity constraints

I suspect that we will understand a 1st order model for theoretical price after this event — assuming a 1-1 peg means 

stETH ≈ e^{(stETH_yield - opportunity_cost_yield - risk_premia)*time_to_merge)} * ETH_price

I’ll try to do a posthoc analysis of risk premia vs. opp cost

@0xRacerAlt I think the problem is you need to actually understand the math to reason about fairness, you can’t get lucky (just look at fairness in AI to give you some evidence of this)

@0xRacerAlt Plotting in Desmos != defining limits of your model (like RMMs)

Limits of your model (formally) = best way to find out how to add in phenomenology you observe that isn’t well described

Claims about fairness and curve design do need a better theoretical framework, it is extremely unlikely you can design a viable curve the current no arbitrage framework but it’s also a bit defeatist for anyone to think “it’s over, RIP good times”

Fairness involves classical notions from many different fields (game theory, AI, statistical learning theory, computational complexity) and is not something you can say, “well geez I plotted this curve that doesn’t get implemented as it seems so it can’t be fair”
I think the idea that one can “play in desmos” and reason about fairness seems a bit narrow minded research wise

In spite of this perhaps (but likely not) putting down people working on RMMs, I think the main point is true and there is Research (capital R) that will accommodate both of Dan’s wishes, should the interested reader learn convex analysis, mempool analysis, and PoA

1. Sample random A factor
2. Process trade against Curve’s invariant with A
3. Round to nearest abc triple around Curve’s cusp

4. The ε in the abc conjecture is actually very likely to be related to the DP one for this CFMM thanks to the Borel-Cantelli lemma (see this great but short Terence Tao post) https://t.co/gGSClczIrd

Why is this funny?
1. ABC@home has enumerated a lot of pairs — almost a “number theoretic PoW” to compute rounded trade size for an adversary
2. Radical calculation easier over ZKR’s finite field (e.g. Mathers-Stothers thm.)
3. Trades concentrate where linear, product terms meet

Big 🧠 CFMM idea on a ZKR:

Differentially private version of Curve where instead of permuting orders, noise, and batching, you round the order to the nearest solution of the abc conjecture (the a+b=c and |abc-rad(c)|< ε  constraints mean you round near Curve’s inflection point)

Open Questions ❓

While simple, this provides some qualitative guidance on designing retroactive airdrops based on expectations of token price behavior (or MM incentives)

What's missing?
1. Game Theory between 🐳🐳 competing for % of retro rewards
2. Dependence on metric h

Expected Time to Exercise ⏲️

One thing this model does is compute the expected time until exercise:
1. Time to exercise 🔼: Price drift 📈, capital used for farming 📈
2. Time to exercise 🔽: Volatility 🔻

There are a lot of measure theoretic annoyances to deal with here that we'll ignore (Shreve and others have done the hard work) but suffice it to say that you _can_ solve a Black-Scholes like model for these options if t* is geometric

So what does this model say about airdrops? https://t.co/LL13ZclsKr

Introducing the 'random-stop' perpetual American option

Recall: Perpetual American options let you exercise at any time post purchase (e.g. Everlasting options is a form of this) — something in the middle is the 'random stop' option: choose t* and only allow exercise for t > t*

Another angle to look at this is in terms of a hurdle rate: 

Given that I receive a certain quantity of options, how much does the token price have to increase to earn more than the "average" rate of return in DeFi?

This implicitly provides you w/ a well-defined strike price!

What are the properties of this implied option?
1. Quantity you get depends on how much you increased the metric h
2. Random time t* such that you can only exercise the option at any time t > t*
3. Strike price is unknown to you (which is a bummer!)

Can we model anything here?

Implicit opportunity cost of capital here: locking up your capital in a protocol that doesn't give you an immediate reward vs. earning yield now

It is as if you bought options on the future token that you can only exercise at some random time in the future (exercise = claiming)

Think of retroactive airdrops in terms of capital optionality:

1. Provide capital (TVL, fees, volume) to a protocol
2. Increases a topline metric h that the snapshot uses
3. At an unknown time in the future you get an airdrop proportional to how much you increased the metric

🌬️💧How should we think about the implied value of a retroactive airdrop?

The process is usually the following:
1. Write long form notes on the problem statement
2. Add in summaries of other papers / relevant literature
3. Add in conjectures 
4. Add in proofs of conjectures as they’re figured out
5. 🔪🔪🔪 cut as much as possible
6. Rewrite concisely

@deadbeatcapital @ks_kulk @zkproofs @dystopiabreaker In continuous space, it's easy to have a gauge bundle for the standard model symmetries, but very hard to make analogues of them in the discrete world that can actually be measured

@deadbeatcapital @ks_kulk @zkproofs @dystopiabreaker No, its that we have a bunch of experiments where we measure these conserved quantities (e.g. exponents of a correlation function) that seemingly match predictions from continuous space much better than discrete space; discrete space needs "emergent" symmetries which is hard
@ssaintleger @dystopiabreaker @zkproofs If Penrose were more consistent w/ experiments I'd agree; QB is probably a somewhat more realistic philosophical take on discrete space
