@Jash__Desai @ks_kulk @zkproofs @dystopiabreaker Yeah, but you can relax isoperimetric inequality to, "invariant by action of G" inequality (isoperimetric ends up just being slightly bigger than "invariant to SO(n)") — which gets you to things like Smirnov's proof of Ising holomorphicity
@Jash__Desai @ks_kulk @zkproofs @dystopiabreaker Similar for CFT — half of the shit in Senechal, Di Francesco, et. al is just impossible to work with mathematically but easy to use for physicists
@Jash__Desai @ks_kulk @zkproofs @dystopiabreaker To me, theoretical stat mech = "anything Talagrand could've proven a concentration inequality for"

@Jash__Desai @ks_kulk @zkproofs @dystopiabreaker I guess its a question of the level of rigor that you want to be at; for instance, things in Atland and Simons I'd consider theoretic condensed matter but not theoretical stat mech — half of the models don't have formal proofs even for mean-field version of them
@Jash__Desai @ks_kulk @zkproofs @dystopiabreaker The conformal bootstrap, for 3D Ising, was a somewhat successful attempt at this, but I haven't followed it in a while
@Jash__Desai @ks_kulk @zkproofs @dystopiabreaker haha, awesome; I had a similar revelation although I went from strings to theoretical stat mech

@Jash__Desai @ks_kulk @zkproofs @dystopiabreaker The problem is, I haven't seen any non-2D construction of such limits that guarantees that the "discrete subgroup" symmetry on the finite lattices/graphs converges (even weakly, only on functions/integrals over the Haar measure) has limit full symmetry

@Jash__Desai @ks_kulk @zkproofs @dystopiabreaker Right, although I'm still not sure if spin foams ever have been shown to realize the weak force symmetries in the limit (but I haven't paid attention to this since 2010, so..)

@Jash__Desai @ks_kulk @zkproofs @dystopiabreaker In the case of Ising, it is of course symmetry to the whole infinite dimensional conformal group, but spin foam seems to be a little more like the "conformal bootstrap" but for groups that are compact (afaict)

@Jash__Desai @ks_kulk @zkproofs @dystopiabreaker Yeah, I think the goal of a spin foam is (and I'm biased because I only really studied stat mech not spin foams) something like what you have with the Ising model: S_n is a set of models on n particles as as n -> infinity you recover, in a correlation function sense, G symmetry
@ks_kulk @zkproofs @dystopiabreaker Yeah roughly

@ks_kulk @zkproofs @dystopiabreaker Problem for quantum gravity: you can’t renormalize because it’s super non-local — hence the extra dimensions in a compact manifold (the volume integral bounds divergence of the expectation of your operators)

@ks_kulk @zkproofs @dystopiabreaker This is why you have effective field theories or renormalization where you cutoff at certain energy/length scales so that you get a convergent answer (which somehow ends up being accurate to 9-10 digits of precision, wildly)

@ks_kulk @zkproofs @dystopiabreaker In the limit of finite hbar, you get divergent series for expectations as a) the time varying metric evolves (e.g. imagine having a positive cosmological constant and distances increase) and b) as the energy series per excitation ~ sum(hbar^n f(E, hbar)) diverges

@ks_kulk @zkproofs @dystopiabreaker But the problem is the quantization that hbar refers to is not a quantization of spacetime but actually a quantization of the spectrum of a Unitary operator (e.g. it has discrete spectrum with finite spectral gap ~ O(hbar^k)

@ks_kulk @zkproofs @dystopiabreaker Zoomed out answer:
- GR time varying metric equations are non-local
- QFT correlation functions are very local
- When you try to merge them, you get weird things that happen (e.g. the amount of energy to push a particle a finite distance goes to infinity)

@ks_kulk @zkproofs @dystopiabreaker QFT itself is very fine in continuous domains though; you can even formalize it directly in terms of operator algebras indexed by R^{3,1}; see below https://t.co/vMk4pQhZcH

@ks_kulk @zkproofs @dystopiabreaker Spin foam = assume spacetime is actually discrete and try to build an approximate metric (“bottom up” approach) 

But it’s not very mainstream / well studied tbh

@ks_kulk @zkproofs @dystopiabreaker Haha, I see that you’re enjoying the conundrum of quantum gravity 😏

Basically all QG mechanics try to embed QFT (described by local operators and their symmetries) into a metric and find consistency between the two; they end up only being able to by adding extra dimensions (rn)

@zkproofs @dystopiabreaker The other thing @dystopiabreaker is missing is that fundamental symmetries of nature are continuous (e.g. SU(3), U(1), etc.) and while these have their own conserved charges that quantize the minimal energy gap differences between excitations… they’re still continuous

@zkproofs @dystopiabreaker Nah, not unless you believe in the spin foam type of stuff; yes, there’s quantization, but @dystopiabreaker is ignoring that you still have a space-time metric and manifold that’s continuous (even though you quantize operators on this manifold)

Generalizations past Ohm?

A. Map @TokenReactor to Ohm ➡️ it is only controllable via RL (not opt. control) due to the curse of dimensionality

B. ve(3,3) and other ve models are solutions to a Hamilton-Jacobi-Isaacs equation— for which showing equilibria exist is nontrivial 😩

Recap:
- Ohm uses optimal control / model predictive control to control its price process via bonds
- With the correct parametrization, the protocol can asymptotically lower its price process variance
- It can lower this variance faster if more durations/bonds are available

You might think this is a limitation/restriction, but thanks to Talagrand’s inequality and universality, you can (relatively easily) lift this to any Lipschitz process w/ independent increments https://t.co/4ijBgngq00

Tool 3: Gaussian Processes 🔧
Since we don’t know the real price process dynamics, we let the *dynamics* themselves be stochastic — drift/volatility are drawn from a Gaussian process

The inequality bounds the evolution of a time-varying process (in the case of Ohm, the expectation of the price process) as a function of upper bounds on derivatives of the process

There exists a recent stochastic analogue that allows us to push our results to Ito diffusions

Tool 2: Grönwall’s inequality 🧰
 
Ever since @ArthurJacot3, @HonglerClement, and @FranckGabriel6 used this inequality to prove the limiting behavior of the Neural Tangent Kernel in Deep Learning, I’ve been looking for a way to use for this inequality in crypto https://t.co/N9NbXLcO7W

Tool 1: Bounding the derivative of the value function via a Lyapunov Method 🗜
 
Using some tricks from classical Lyapunov methods, we were able to get a bound on the time derivative of the ‘value function’ (think: RL) that measures how fast we can change the functional value: https://t.co/lRU7mIVJ4j

This is *the* qualitative difference between Ohm bonds and PID-like mechanisms — they end up in asymptotically different states with regard to how well they can control these systems

We generalized this result to stochastic dynamics — so what tools did we use to prove this? ⛏

For the unconstrained model, we’re able to show two things:

1. Mean-variance optimization = linear-quadratic regulator

2. As you increase the number of bonds *the controller gets better* (e.g. it minimizes the functional *faster*) https://t.co/PKxQOXw0Sx

We study two versions of ℓ: one unconstrained and quadratic and the other constrained

Unconstrained: mean-variance optimization (analyzed theoretically)
 
Constrained: adds constraints to ensure inflation doesn’t grow too fast, protocol doesn’t spend too much (numerical only) https://t.co/CvTFpq8iGs

Step 2: Define a functional that measures ‘controller quality’ (e.g.  π, i) based on how well it has controlled the price process P(t) (e.g. variance minimized)

Step 3: Compute the controls π, i that optimize the functional — and then use them in production and repeat steps 1-3 https://t.co/TEsj80aMxa

Once you look at Ohm from yields instead of prices, you can start pulling out tools from optimal control

Step 1: Construct a controlled stochastic process for Ohm’s price where the Ohm mechanism adjusts π (Ohm yield spent on each type of bond) and i (inflation rate at time t) https://t.co/NLgWlXenij

OG Ohm bond controller: written by @ohmzeus, is a non-linear controller that is hard to analyze — we begin by formulating this controller mathematically
 
Controller is spec'd in terms of price discounts — each bond spec'd by a duration + a price discount parameter (nonlinearity) https://t.co/ibuo3nhqeQ

Our question: Does having many different types of bonds help the protocol in its goals of reducing price volatility?
 
It turns out the answer is yes! But first, we need to spend a little time understanding the Ohm mechanism from the lens of optimal control. https://t.co/l6IJweq3Yl

Ohm introduced a bonding mechanism which allowed the protocol to grow its treasury and ensure that liquidity added to the system is 'sticky'
 
Bonding allows people to lock in multiple types of collateral — ETH, LP shares — in exchange for linearly vesting future Ohm rewards https://t.co/Ff36z1jezq

In 2020, @htkao and I wrote a blog post about how many (really most) DeFi mechanisms resemble control mechanisms; at that time, everything we found was basically a PID controller.
 
But we had hopes for optimal control and beyond entering DeFi as illustrated in this figure: https://t.co/EsDCJaEESL

It is clear that algo ‘stablecoins’ involve control theory — but prior to Ohm, most failed attempts (e.g. Basis, ESD) relied on PIDish controllers
 
Mechanisms had ‘control variables’ (e.g. bonds/locked assets) which couldn't reduce price variance/drift
 
https://t.co/OhtUHf6gss

@michaeljcurry1 Yeah, for sure, there is some overlap (personally, I tried to make the overlap explicit in one paper of mine that looks at privacy vs. utility trade-offs) but I think its pretty small right now

@michaeljcurry1 Also, cryptographers and those in DeFi want to minimize recovery probability; researchers in ML (minus those in private and to some extent robust ML) focus on maximizing recovery probability and this leads to different techniques/tools/thought processes

@michaeljcurry1 There's also a sense in which cryptographers hope for minimax bounds *always* whereas DL focuses on purely concentration / probabilistic bounds; DeFi research is squarely in the middle of the two

@michaeljcurry1 I guess I see the theoretical tools and goals in quite an opposite light; for instance, cryptographers tend to underweight their usage of probability whereas learning theorists focus much more on concentration-style bounds

@karimhelpme This does gets to this point: apps that have unstructured, non-atomic transactions make this worse

@karimhelpme MEV for Solana (without @jito_labs) is probably closer in complexity to NN-style stuff
@karimhelpme Even with MEV, the maximal set of forks is bounded if you have a buffer (e.g. via a buffer / mempool)

@karimhelpme Perhaps, but the MEV state space is more well-defined; if I compare a d layer NN and a (d+1) layer NN, depending on the weight initialization and data regularity (or lack thereof), you will have trouble bounding the increase in computational complexity (which isn't true for MEV)

@karimhelpme Also Probabilistic != non-asymptotic results 🙃

Neural net theorems almost always assume some type of random weight initialization (so are also probabilistic but over weights and sometimes input data sets)
@karimhelpme Asymptotic in time is the same in both cases (e.g. the neural tangent kernel scales time and kernel width at the same time), but I meant more in terms of spatial dimensions / state

@0xalpharush @nope_its_lily In an ideal world, yes; but The set of methods to reduce the set of paths has cardinality greater than the set of paths, so you end up needing to have some experience / heuristics in practice. Perhaps this is also why “no code ML” hasn’t doesn’t particularly well

@0xalpharush @nope_its_lily Searching through the path space inevitably will rely on a prior distribution that is not uniform over all trajectories (like fuzzing). There’s a reason AlphaGo and AlphaZero learn quite constrained distributions (trained policy networks) before doing combinatorial search (MCTS)

@0xalpharush @nope_its_lily Right, but fuzzing is not a hypothesis test in the classical statistical sense; a hypothesis test involves a model, a parameter space, a metric on that parameter space, and a region that is “null” in the parameter space. Usually this involves non-uniform searching (e.g. MLE, MAP)
@0xalpharush @nope_its_lily The difference, however, is that you’re constructing probabilistic hypothesis tests instead of looking for formal properties that have to hold always

@0xalpharush @nope_its_lily Risk simulation has similarity to what you do as a smart contract auditor — yes, the tools like Slither are there, but if you don’t know how to write the models / tests in a way that covers as much of the search space as possible you can be misled to think something is safe

@badcryptobitch @cupidhack Rough use of fairness here = maximizing revenue + social welfare (e.g. utilities of all participants) vs. maximizing revenue alone)

@badcryptobitch @cupidhack You have a trade-off between best clearing price and fair allocation to participants; so to 1st order E[revenue + social welfare] ~ Ω(highest_bid + Var[BidsDistribution]) — the latter is maximized if you have a pure random sample

@badcryptobitch @cupidhack There are a lot of batch auction style designs for loading the first bid into a collateral auction; right now, such designs don't really work because you can't trustlessly guarantee that you've selected fairly from the batch

@garybasin @hdevalence @tszzl @dystopiabreaker @GuilleAngeris @alexhevans @fractional_art Another example is automatically making new products as a function of trigger events (e.g. create a new strip of options for asset X when event Y happens) — CEXs can't do this freely for regulatory reasons + technical reasons (interop of the products between exchanges)

@garybasin @hdevalence @tszzl @dystopiabreaker @GuilleAngeris @alexhevans @fractional_art The genesis growth of Uniswap was the MKR/DAI pool, which was notable because CEXs refused to list MKR for a long time (for a variety of reasons --- regulatory, irregular supply, hard to read contracts)

@garybasin @hdevalence @tszzl @dystopiabreaker @GuilleAngeris @alexhevans @fractional_art You're paying in a) latency and b) adverse selection for LPs due to the deterministic slippage

But that might make sense for some assets!

@garybasin @hdevalence @tszzl @dystopiabreaker @GuilleAngeris @alexhevans @fractional_art There's also a future in which entities can create and destroy assets at will, allowing for "just-in-time" capital formation which is way more efficient than the current fund structures

@garybasin @hdevalence @tszzl @dystopiabreaker @GuilleAngeris @alexhevans @fractional_art For sure, but if you're launching a new asset you're on a different part of that trade-off curve than someone making an IPO — most of the value still comes from the fact that you can do capital formation for cheaper (which *is* valuable!)

@garybasin @hdevalence @tszzl @dystopiabreaker @GuilleAngeris @alexhevans @fractional_art Another way to look at it: for long-tail and new assets, you basically get the infrastructure of trading GE strips for 1/100000th the cost!
@garybasin @hdevalence @tszzl @dystopiabreaker @GuilleAngeris @alexhevans @fractional_art *distributed systems

@garybasin @hdevalence @tszzl @dystopiabreaker @GuilleAngeris @alexhevans @fractional_art I just mainly think its better to view a lot of DeFi from the lens of distributed system where you get guarantees on execution, atomicity, and liveness that previously you relied on trust in venues or infrastructure (e.g. McKay) to receive

@garybasin @hdevalence @tszzl @dystopiabreaker @GuilleAngeris @alexhevans @fractional_art This doesn't really happen in normal trading — can I actually certify that McKay Brothers gave me best execution / ordered correctly? In AMM-land, however, you can actually construct such proofs since the liquidity/routing data is public and slippage is directly computable

@garybasin @hdevalence @tszzl @dystopiabreaker @GuilleAngeris @alexhevans Overcollateralized loans on liquid assets being automated is the first step to loans on illiquid assets (e.g. using @fractional_art or bond-like mechanisms)

Another useful thing is that you can inter-venue trades (routing) where the router can prove it gave you the best route

@garybasin @hdevalence @tszzl @dystopiabreaker @GuilleAngeris @alexhevans In fact, there are many trading strategies that exist to basically estimate the size of an implied order on the main order book based on how long a spread product takes to execute. That latency is to "CME goes through order book in O(orders) time to decide is spread works"

@garybasin @hdevalence @tszzl @dystopiabreaker @GuilleAngeris @alexhevans Another distributed systems component of why AMMs can be better than order books is that they’re better for liquidity providers when liveness is lost (e.g. Solana liveness event in Fall)

See: https://t.co/pjEuHuoBLH

@garybasin @hdevalence @tszzl @dystopiabreaker @GuilleAngeris @alexhevans The idea of having an exchange that ensures atomic guarantees (e.g. O(1) state update cost vs. O(liquidity)) changes how you interact with the exchange and makes automating certain types of transactions a lot easier (e.g. lender liquidations)

@garybasin @hdevalence @tszzl @dystopiabreaker @GuilleAngeris @alexhevans One thing that took me a long time to appreciate after being in HFT is that the “minimize gas fees to trade” component is deeper than that — you actually ensure atomicity of trade operations which lets you compose more easily than an order book (e.g. why flash loan liqs work)

@KentoInami @0xmons Yes, but there's also not a unique limit from discrete -> continuous [to see why, consider a stochastic price process and think about the difference between the Ito and Stratanovich integrals — same thing applies here]

@KentoInami @0xmons Another way to think about it:

AMM Sharpe / ROI is a smooth function of volatility of the price process

CLOB Sharpe / ROI is not a smooth function

"Continuous CLOB" ROI is smooth, but not unique

@KentoInami @0xmons The continuous limit does exist (e.g. tick size -> 0  while keeping density of trades / price constant) but is not unique. Again, I'd refer you to classical papers to see why this is true https://t.co/yzvhq6oTbh
@alexhevans RH considered harmful

@KentoInami @0xmons I'd suggest reading Bouchaud if you want the basics, but its a complex field (especially in practice, most quant trading firms spend a lot of their time perfecting their model for what you're calling ROI and it isn't static whatsoever)

@KentoInami @0xmons Not quite, the ROI depends on how often you have to quote which depends on a) gas fee b) trade size (e.g. a trade that wipes out the book will cause you a bigger hit ROI-wise) and c) how aggressively you quote

There's a reason this is hard to model in TradFi
@KentoInami @0xmons Also depends on the price / volatility / properties of the asset you're looking at. Mean-reverting assets can be worse in order books

@KentoInami @0xmons Really depends on how aggressively people are quoting, minimum lot size, and the trade distributions; you can model out CFMM performance with less of a dependence on this (which is why they're better on-chain)

@0xmons @KentoInami Wrote one paper on it, but its actually quite complex since order books are discrete objects that approximate continuous ones and thus have a combinatorially big state space

MICPs, however, admit Sum-of-Squares proofs that can be used to certify optimality

B. What if instead we said, "can we design a CFMM such that the routing problem [e.g. the MICP] is easy?" This is in the vein of @algo_class's "Theory of DeFi?" talk — if we invert the design problem, we might get much richer phenomena / better protocols

https://t.co/yfyukjnVdF

5. Finally, we generalize the problem to one with transaction costs and show that it is not convex; however, it *can* be solved with an mixed-integer convex program [MICP] (like Mosek/Gurobi) — which is awesome, you can throw computers at the problem not peoples' chalkboards! https://t.co/bSuiFNKcEM

4. Remember how if a CFMM has a fee γ, then there's a price interval ~ [1/(1-γ) spot, (1+γ) spot] where arbitrageurs are unprofitable (e.g. CFMM price is stale)?

We generalize that interval to the multi-CFMM case using Lagrange Multipliers λ (yes, freshman calc is still useful) https://t.co/gt43yDSbsL

2. Define a general flow vector Ψ that captures the trades executed within a single CFMM vs. the others routed through multiple CFMMs

3.  Given a utility function U(Ψ), we construct a fee-less problem for optimal routing and show that its convex (= easy to solve numerically) https://t.co/cb2akDLoj8

Unlike prior academic work that focused on explicit analytic max-flow solutions for routing (which only works for the simplest CFMMs, like Uniswap), we take a computational approach 👇🏾

1. Frame the problem as a matching-like problem on a bipartite graph made of CFMMs and tokens https://t.co/9nXhQbd89T

The space of studying how DeFi applications interact with consensus is wide open — other than our differential privacy paper and this work, we haven't seen much, but II'm sure this is just the tip of the iceberg https://t.co/xrkRICNAqR

In the appendix, we spend some time trying to relate consensus protocol liveness to application-specific liveness and construct a game between an adversary trying to DDoS (increase # of txns) vs. a player trying to execute > X trades — there is a saddle point / Nash equilibrium! https://t.co/UHjlYTir3V

Curious observation: Applications (not just consensus protocols) have their own notion of liveness that is dependent on more than network latency / TPS / bandwidth (e.g. how many trades can I service given liquidity L, synchrony constant τ, max trade size T?) https://t.co/XSfIDqISpT

Network w/ block size B halts; upon regaining liveness, we will need N(Δp) < B to ensure that on-chain and off-chain prices can be synchronized

Since B is a fixed, we see that unbounded price support CFMMs *always* survive liveness loss (formalizes this) 
https://t.co/RlX78zW6xs

Suppose N(Δp) is the number of transactions needed to adjust liquidity under a price change of Δp

For UniV2/Balancer/Curve, N(Δp) is constant in Δp to update liquidity, N(Δp) = Θ(1)

For UniV3/OB, N(Δp) is linear in Δp, N(Δp) =  Ω(Δp)

This is a big gap, especially w/o liveness! https://t.co/Mmzq37qyJU

Even worse: There's a race condition for order books between LPs/MMs trying to cancel orders and liquidators trying to get their liquidation filled against the last quote price in an OB

Do CFMMs have the same race condition? Surprisingly, no! 🤠
  https://t.co/nTVoeaK4v3

Intuition 🧐: 
Unbounded CFMMs buy the worst asset as prices go down BUT LPs always own a non-zero amount of the better asset — isn't true for UniV3 (can end up with only the bad side) when there's a large price gap

Liquidations against unbd. CFMMs = gradual, smooth price drop https://t.co/qWJChkmBrh

Since bounded support CFMMs (concentrated liquidity) are eq. to pro-rata order books, this shows that LPs have *worse* asymptotic losses in OBs when there is a larger price gap between off-chain and on-chain prices

Network down longer → larger expected price gap → LPs ngmi https://t.co/SObHLQm5XA

We analyzed *asymptotic portfolio value* (APV)

Portfolio Value (PV): Value of LP shares in numéraire terms when price is p
APV: How does PV(p) change as p → 0, p → ∞?

Unbounded CFMMs (UniV2), PV(p) = o(p) (sublinear in p)
Bounded support CFMMs (UniV3): PV(p) = Ω(p) (linear)

@Music109025311 Yeah, there’s a mean-field limit where you rescale liquidity / discretization unit as something like 1/curvature * sqrt(discretization unit) and take n -> infinity where they’re equal; some classical order book theory (e.g. Bouchaud) does this, but without knowing about CFMMs)
n here is some compatible measure of liquidity (number of resting orders and/or discretization of the amount of liquidity locked into a CFMM pool)

Being compatible with atomic operations is the main reason that CFMMs (O(1) update) are significantly more robust than order books (worst case O(n) updates) on-chain

Takeaways:
1. Can go further than we thought *w/o lending/leverage* for complex financial products (even convex ones!)
2. Fractionalizing LP shares gets leverage-like exposure w/o liquidation risk
3. Staking Derivatives & DAO treasuries: natural home for these products https://t.co/BFJJ6iYKRP

CPPI:
We had heard remarks like “how can [RMMs + convex analysis] replicate the fact that Uniswap is a 50% wealth allocation to each asset?"

We show that the *unique* constant proportion wealth allocation CFMM invariant is the geometric mean of @Uniswap and @BalancerLabs https://t.co/14WtoUsh1m

Capped Power Payoffs:
Given the interest in power perpetuals (@_Dave__White_ / @opyn_)...

Q: Implement them in a far more gas and liquidation efficient manner than the original paper?
A: Yes if bounded! 

The formulas are reminiscent of Rényi entropy (seems non-coincidental..) https://t.co/YLulQjbcuL

Variance Swaps:
One of the most traded derivatives are variance swaps — this work improves upon our previous work by providing an explicit CFMM function (again, no oracles!) https://t.co/FmlwX1M2La

Binary Black-Scholes Calls:
Want to make a simple Arrow-Debreu prediction market (no oracle!) priced via Black-Scholes? Here's the portfolio construction cost and trading function https://t.co/CSsAXewc96

From this formula, we get a number of cool properties
1. Replication must be asymptotically linear (but can be *any* bounded support function!)
2. Optimal arbitrage profit >= 0
3. Arbitrage profit is *exactly* the sum of impermanent loss - cost of constructing portfolio https://t.co/tEfg0zATLO

How? Contract:

Consider an LP (👩‍🚒) with ETH/USDC share
a. 👩‍🚒sells the *rights* to the USDC side of the pool to counterparty 👨‍🎤 via contract
b. 👨‍🎤 can execute the contract → liquidates LP share, gives USDC to 👨‍🎤, ETH to👩‍🚒

∴ 👩‍🚒only owns ETH exposure, 👨‍🎤 owns USDC + exec. risk

First, why would you want to do this? It improves over RMMs + lending in the following ways
a. ⛽️📉 Gas costs go down
b. ☔️ No liquidation risk
c. 🔮 No oracles 
d. 🧮 Plays well staking derivatives

This also makes the exposure ideal for DAO treasuries (no active management!) https://t.co/RavU0mpTzq

Before: Showed 1-homogenous, concave payoffs can be exactly replicated by CFMMs (e.g. Uniswap V3)

Also: Any bounded (range + support) convex payoff by borrowing against LP shares (e.g. @MakerDAO / @AaveAave)

But lending’s a lotta work, can we get these payoffs w/o leverage? https://t.co/DyCDiVUuae

🌜New Paper: Monotone Payoffs🌛

Past: Replicate bounded payoffs w/ CFMM leverage
Now: Replicate many bounded payoffs *w/o* leverage

The gang (@guilleangeris, @alexhevan + moi) improves on CFMMs with binary options, variance swaps w/o oracles, and more™️

@hdevalence Yeah, I agree that the batching of chains removes some of the racing behavior but not all; the MEV auctions on different chains will, for instance, be impacted by bridge txns of high value and that is still a race

@hdevalence The idea of competition for limited bandwidth between different machines and a (small) set of parties that control FFI execution between state machines is the part that’s similar between bridges / microwaves

@hdevalence I guess the main part of the analogy is that you might see a rush to multiple bridges that provide different features but only 1 survives (c.f. The Hummingbird Project)

Technically, the main analogy is that it’s an RPC call between different state machines w/ competition for bw

For instance, bridges that preserve composability or allow for chained function call FFI between different VMs will have worse UX (more state mgmt for devs) than bridges focused on single swaps/transfers and this seems to be (at least now) a fundamental difference

One of the most important questions that will get answered in prod in the next few years

The model of bridges ~ microwave towers from HFT only works if liquidity doesn’t fragment; but given the highly varied QoS / bandwidth of different bridge protocols, I’d bet many live

@secparam @_mahimna I generally think that just as there is the duality between differential privacy and online learning (c.f. Alon, Bun, etc.), there is also a duality between bits of info. per transaction vs. maximum MEV profit

@secparam @_mahimna For instance, a sequence of cascading liquidations is much more 'long-ranged' in a block than a single sandwich attack and each of these will create a different trade off between utility (price impact/liquidation) vs. privacy (learnable bits about a transaction)

@secparam @_mahimna Good question: It definitely shifts the curve in one manner (e.g. you need added verifiable randomness plus  worse price impact to ensure an adversary can't impute your trade w/ more than k-bits of precision), but different forms of MEV can be quite different

@phildaian @_mahimna This threat model is much closer to the flood we saw on Solana yesterday where a message buffer was overloaded (similar to how the waiting graphs for computing tx ordering can be DDoS'd)

@phildaian @_mahimna But the threat model in both papers doesn't consider adaptive adversaries who can flood with "fake" transactions (paper's terminology) — I think you need to show the "size of txn block" vs. latency curve is bad for the adaptive model to conclusively get to where you want to be

@phildaian @_mahimna There is a sort of partial result of this form in the original FSS paper with approx. order fairness (it has a latency trade off using ξ) — this led to them to weaken to block order fairness

You probably want some type of trade off between "block size" and latency https://t.co/1M0ymZpJ9D

@phildaian @_mahimna But its not an impossibility result, just a sign that you either need a) dramatically different proof techniques or b) there's an impossibility result w/ the right threat model formulation

@phildaian @_mahimna Well, the constants and weak probability techniques in fair sequencing papers makes it seem quite hard to generalize FSS to adaptive adversaries who can flood the network w/ lots of cyclic transactions, forcing view changes

In particular, adaptive adversaries can drive the latency up quite a bit by forcing a lot of Condorcet 3-cycles (e.g. stake weighted vote says tx1 < tx2, tx2 < tx3, tx3 < tx1) which increases the processing time to pick a final ordering https://t.co/Rwjlvba8M3

The proofs often only guarantee properties about expected delays / expected latency — but the probabilistic methods used are too weak to give strong tail bounds

Adding in MEV prevention tools like FSS might lead to higher queueing problems like we saw yesterday with Solana https://t.co/9d9o00Vcja

Lately, esp. given liveness issues in L1s (low latency, low uptime), I think of MEV as much as an economic issue as a UX issue — you can't reduce it without reducing liveness/p95 & p99 latency

FSS papers by @_mahimna, et. al are v. cool but have *really* bad latency guarantees

Having had to learn this material myself from reading papers for 4-5 years, this seems like a much more pleasant and direct way to get to the state of the art

@huitseeker @luca_defeo This is quite an interdisciplinary paper and the last time I spent a month understanding a Wesolowski paper, I came away with a lot of confidence in his level of rigor and care in his proofs (which I can't say I believe for all of crypto)

@huitseeker @luca_defeo The facts that a) the lattice constructed by the endomorphisms (modulo some symmetry) is a Clifford algebra and b) the Generalized Riemann Hypothesis bounds orders of elements in the algebra are really wild and completely unintuitive to me (even though I used to do DG/AG)

@huitseeker @luca_defeo The result itself, as far as I understand, resolves a conjecture about the SIDH security assumption ("I can't invert a random walk on the isogeny graph given only the endpoints") and it's relation to a more well-known/understood security assumption (endomorphism degrees)

@huitseeker @luca_defeo My interest in it is basically because it reduces a problem in probability on groups (expected cover time of random walks on isogeny groups) to a purely algebraic property — this rarely happens in probability and is usually a sign of magic

3. Minimum number of birth-death creation pairs
4. Instance specific gas usage

What’s the upshot of all of this?
1. Mixing lots of disciplines can be occasionally be fruitful
2. Diff. Priv. Uniswap isn’t too hard, you mainly need a VRF + consensus-controlled CFMM (@osmosiszone, @penumbrazone)
3. Pr[L1s / L2s will offer this as a differentiator to ETH] = 1

This paper, thanks to me sadly, is quite different from our other papers in that its a) combinatorial not convex analytic and b) uses a lot of tools from disparate fields, e.g.
1. Diff. Privacy
2. Branching random walks
3. Private PAC learning
4. Generic Chaining

I got the idea for inverting Alon’s paper while I was in a four hour car ride w/ @pplpleasr1 but it took a month of beating my head against the 🌲 (literally) to prove this works — boils down to bounding CFMM's curvature (proxy for “liquidity concentration”) in the right manner https://t.co/92nqUHLDTd

1. Show height/num. leaves of trade tree bounds worst case price impact
2. Add noise/split trades to make tree Θ(log T) height for T trades

Remember why QuickSort runs in O(log n)?

This uses stronger results (below) of that form to dramatically to control price impact https://t.co/4fwcRUtY8Y

🌲🌲🌲
How do we do this? I sort of inverted the construction of Alon, et. al — can we construct a “worst case” combinatorial object whose "complexity" (e.g. VC dim) is a cost of privacy? I constructed a discrete object called a trade tree made of partial sums of trades https://t.co/QF5DpNBO4G

In the paper, we propose a parametrized algorithm — permute + split + noise
- Add noise to trades so we don’t look like a threshold
- Split big trades (does cost $/fees)
- Randomly permute trade ordering before execution (using a VRF)

This achieves (ε, δ)-differential privacy!

OTOH, MEV is high without batching if you can learn thresholds: front run the 🐳 & sell to orders after the whale at a higher price

tl;dr: Batching — large price impact; no batching — no privacy, high MEV

Can we do better? Can we have provable privacy guarantees and cost est.?

Consider a sequence of T trades w/ sizes T, 1, …, 1 — 1 🐳, T-1 🐟— ID'ing where the 🐳’s trade gets executed can be viewed as a threshold function (WhaleTradeOrder > k)

Batch auctions are bad for this sequence: they make the worst case price impact Ω(T) — 🐟 pay for the 🐳 https://t.co/Kwpn2uIvo6

Alon, et. al illustrated that a) threshold functions are the hardest to online learn and make private and b) they’re the worst case for *both* online learning and privacy

Why is this relevant to CFMMs? They’re also the worst case for privacy and learnability in trading! https://t.co/L0ACboJ34j

I spent months formulating things using online learning, but kept getting stuck

Then I ran this work of @algo_class, @nhaghtal, @AShettyV where I learned fantastical results from Alon, Bun, etc. that 

Differentially Privacy <=> Online Learnability

https://t.co/zvShMHAZcy

Why online learning? It’s because of MEV, stupid!

If an adversary sees a subset of trades + prices, say (T1, p1), .., (T5, p5), and that’s enough for them to predict T6 with high probability, that’s bad (front runs T6!)

Notions of privacy for CFMMs *need* to represent this

CFMMs privacy is similar! If I have a batch of trades T1, .., Tn, how much noise do I have to add to the prices so an adversary can’t estimate trade sizes w/ high probability

One diff: we care about something stronger — how well can an adversary *online* learn the trade sizes? https://t.co/vBx5ZbUvnT

Unlike FHE or ZKPs, DP provides partial privacy guarantees by trading off accuracy for privacy

It does this by adding noise to a database such that *average* values are preserved but in a way that an adversary can’t figure out any *individual’s* data with appreciable probability https://t.co/v1yrFQzW1b

Of these options, batching has been most adopted in practice (e.g. @MEVprotection, @OsmosisDAO, @penumbrazone)

But what are its privacy vs. cost guarantees? Are we sure it is private over _all_ sequences of trades? 

This led me down the rabbit hole of differential privacy (DP)

On 3/1 @GuilleAngeris, @alexhevans & I wrote a paper showing that you can infer trade sizes in CFMMs like Uniswap strictly from price — convexity: blessing for arbitrage, curse for privacy (even w/ ZKPs)

But we left two opportunities for partial privacy (https://t.co/QihLCm6bGB) https://t.co/BjQZrFjreC

@thegostep @SiegeRhino2 @0xtuba @Mellowprotocol . @GuilleAngeris @alexhevans and I considered a system with (1), (4), (5), (6) and recovered the classical Glosten-Milgrom result that (4) needs to exist and that (1) only makes money if trades are always “small”

@thegostep @SiegeRhino2 @0xtuba @Mellowprotocol I think the better classification of the agents in the system are:
1. Fully Passive LP
2. Automated reallocation LP
3. Manually active LP
4. Noise trader
5. Informed trader
6. Arbitrageur

The last three are “takers” and the market isn’t stable without (1) and (4)

@thegostep @SiegeRhino2 @0xtuba Hard for the whole market to be a JIT though; the Uniswap reallocation strategies like @Mellowprotocol are probably the first attempts at JITing

Normal MMs either do JIT (sweep book around big orders, quote massive size around big orders) or hedge in options but usually not both

@AnalystDC @fractional_art @matt_levine Usually forced liquidation is a bug not a feature (e.g. only done at bankruptcy) — but in NFT land it is a feature [provides price discovery / effectively allows for 'M&A' of assets all at once]

@AnalystDC @fractional_art @matt_levine 1. They determine the NAV calculation because they vote on the floor price for the NAV (which is the initial auction price)

2. 'Calculation day' is forced by any market participant at any time (e.g. you can tender an offer and the token holders can vote on min price for offer)

@AnalystDC @fractional_art @matt_levine Right there are two things here that are underspecified:
1. Who computes the NAV and who decides on the NAV calculation?
2. Who determines the calculation days?

In fractionalized NFTs, token holders determine both of these and the NAV value is determined by an instant auction

@AnalystDC @fractional_art @matt_levine The main value the fractional shares have is not simply "1/x of the asset" --- but it is also the right to vote on the reserve price of the next auction

This last part is really hard to automate in tradfi (can be done, banks are just lazy + lawyers enjoy the fees)

@AnalystDC @fractional_art @matt_levine The main difference here is that creation-redemption arb assumes that the manager/underwriter can rebalance the assets in the pool; here, we instead have 1-1 items (single NFT) that needs to be liquidated all at once if the shares cause a deemed liquidation event (NFT xfer)

@AnalystDC @fractional_art @matt_levine For NFTs you have:
1. Lock NFT into vault, create shares
2. Users buy shares (w/ maybe fee to manager/creator)
3. Users can sell shares (no redemption)
4. *anyone* forces liquidation (e.g. auction to sell NFT)

This is equiv. to buying entire portfolio of a liquid alt via auction

@AnalystDC @fractional_art @matt_levine Usually you have:
1. Underwriter creates shares
2. Users can deposit assets, mint share
3. User can redeem share for some assets
4. Manager rebalances

Now, if someone wants to buy the whole portfolio from the manager, they can't really do it
@kaiynne Welcome! I'm sure you'll enjoy it here, it is quite a great summer

@AnalystDC @fractional_art @matt_levine Each time an NFT is fractionalized it is a "new" product (like a liquid alt w/ daily redemption) albeit with its own auction that is automatically created/destroyed

In a traditional vehicle, construction/destruction of an asset is expensive / needs lawyers doesn't happen in 15s

@AnalystDC @fractional_art @matt_levine In @fractional_art, any buyer who wants to do a buyout can start an auction and token holders vote on the reserve price for the auction — there's no restriction on when/how this gets done

@AnalystDC @fractional_art @matt_levine You can't force a buyout aucton at any point in time — there's usually a redemption window + fixed NAV:basket payout

If you want to do an auction, you have to convince an exchange or third-party to run it for you

4/ Expected Utility Portfolio

We provide some LP strategies for different utility functions

If we view an LP’s contribution to a CFMM pool as a portfolio allocation, we explicitly find both linear and Markowitz convex programs for how to optimize LP allocation

Finally, exchange functions generalize the invariant calculation done by @CurveFinance to general CFMM curves

There's a simple Newton iteration (gradient descent) for computing trade size from exch. functions

[Remember when @samczsun found a bug in curve's Newton iteration?] https://t.co/1yxm8tA2uA

Their metric properties, which do depend on a particular parametrization and reserve, are shown to be easily computed numerically

This, again, is very useful for measuring impact to concentrated liquidity (e.g. you can extend by linearity exchange functions to piecewise convex) https://t.co/cUiBH5AFJ4

2/ Explicit formulas for add/remove liquidity

Previous papers assumed reserves were constant

We provide a connection between the trading function gradient and the change to liquidity ▶️ helps improve concentrated liquidity formulas (e.g. @Uniswap V3)

e.g. result below: https://t.co/A8cNyeX8EJ

We also show a few new nifty features of CFMMs

@yaron_velner @bcmakes @hasufl @mevintern Consider this distribution from a *small* set of rational functions that has a complex phase diagram https://t.co/8YOxjZ1Ysq https://t.co/FT3hWDqyUi

@yaron_velner @bcmakes @hasufl @mevintern If there’s such a transition, honest as a delta function supported on a single strategy is qualitatively different than a bounded rationality system (and you can have multiple phases/sets of disconnected equilibria)

@yaron_velner @bcmakes @hasufl @mevintern This happens in algorithmic game theory when you have a pure strategy and set of mixed strategies that are both Nash, but *only* all players playing the pure strategy is a correlated equilibria

@yaron_velner @bcmakes @hasufl @mevintern Perhaps; there’s a singular definition now (it’s a delta function in the space of strategies). Going to a set of non-trivial measure (of course, choosing measures on infinite dimensional function spaces is its own issue) might still have a phase transition

@yaron_velner @bcmakes @hasufl @mevintern You used a *universal quantifier* — does not provide *any* security guarantee — prove that for all subsets of rational strategies we have incentive  non-compliance then

The for all is very hard to make strong claims about.
@yaron_velner @bcmakes @hasufl @mevintern I agree it weakens it, but I would never make such a strong claim as “Nakamoto is broken” without providing much stronger evidence.

@yaron_velner @bcmakes @hasufl @mevintern I am including that in this, such as @stonecoldpat0’s initial excellent paper on this — conveying 51% coherence to a smart contract involves “rational” agents conveying they’re agreeing via a bond, which we’ve yet to see and which only hold for quasi linear utilities

@yaron_velner @bcmakes @hasufl @mevintern Always hard, and never fully satisfactorily dealt with, is what “rational” means. This may sound purely philosophical but quantitatively this will have a dramatic effect on your prediction (e.g. for what utilities, if you’re utilitarian, can I enforce 1000 block coherence?)

@yaron_velner @bcmakes @hasufl @mevintern It’s hard practically to actually enforce coordination; MEV is our first realization of an unstable equilibrium, but I think rational agents won’t necessary be coherent packets for so long (time value of money/block reward)

@yaron_velner @bcmakes @hasufl @mevintern You’re assuming miners are also computationally unbounded agents who somehow can assess that bid quickly and execute on it while coordinating with other big pools in time

@yaron_velner @bcmakes @hasufl @mevintern Good luck, hope you do it and prove me wrong (e.g. get over coordination cost, natural inability for someone to figure out how much they’ll spend on such an attack)

@yaron_velner @bcmakes @hasufl @mevintern Mathematically, the moment you constrain “rational” behavior you force concentration behavior (in the sense of conc. of measure) over their strategies

Your ad hoc analysis ignores this competely

@yaron_velner @bcmakes @hasufl @mevintern The fork probability decays, but so does the net EV of fork. One is guaranteed O(exponential decay) and the other is bursty — if I’m risk averse in *any* sense (which constrains “rational”) then the one block and k block attack probability aren’t that dissimilar

@yaron_velner @bcmakes @hasufl @mevintern Rational agents are computationally and opportunity size bounded. If they really want to try to excoriate a side effect of MEV from 5000 blocks ago, be my guest and good luck — it better be a Shiba airdrop size bounty for the compute cost you’ll spend (let alone data/query costs)

The last portion comes from the fact that the ILP that we propose is qualitatively similar to that of Baldwin and Klemperer, who study the product-mix auction, a form of "one-shot" auction that was used during the financial crisis by the BoE for rev. repo https://t.co/BlwWqU6lN9

A few extensions of our results: 
1. Modified program to handle individual users that have multiple bundle constraints (e.g. try sandwich, but happy w/ backrun)
2. Total gas constraints

What's missing?
- Simulation PNL errors -> how stable is ILP?
- Relationship to deep geometry

We basically encode the bundle optimization problem as a constrained matching problem — how should we pack frontruns, backruns, and sandwiches around a specific set of update transactions?

The ILP proposed is pretty simple and can be solved with conventional tools 🤠

I feel like there’s some nice intersection of algorithmic game theory and concentration inequalities hidden here if you want to make up a fun, somewhat meaningless homework problem from this scenario 🙃😵‍💫

Why? Adding the permutation will change the reserve price sequence, which adapts (via the “loss” f) to the reordering. If it’s size-biased, then you make the bigger chunks sold earlier which means you start with lower prices -> hard to get to highest total clearing price

My bet is that if the reserve prices are i.i.d. and bounded away from zero, then for a size-biased permutation (e.g. Pitman-Yor distribution) then it goes up; however, if the reserves depend on the previous clearing price, r[i] = f(p[i-1]) for monotone f, then it goes down w.h.p.

Let’s suppose this happened and that each of n auctions sells quantities q1, …, qn of bonds

If I take a permutation π and redo the auction but with sizes sj = π(q1, …, qn)_j, will the total notional value of bonds sold in the numéraire go up, down, or stay the same?

@tolstoybb @synthetix_io Basically:
1. ERC-20 minter adds X tokens to SNX mintr contract
2. You mint LP share w/ ERC-20 + ETH
3. You stake the share; if your shares are y% of the pool and the mintr is set up to do X tokens over 1y, you get y% * X tokens after 1y of staking

@tolstoybb The DEX isn't 'printing' the coins; they were minted by a deployed ERC-20 contract and then when you stake an LP share, you get paid; @synthetix_io invented this in early 2020 https://t.co/5R7NTwYjh1

@HunterRMcDonald @TheStalwart Uniswap LP shares are a form of structured product that trades off fee drag for portfolio tracking error in a way that's annoyingly hard to do in normal finance (especially for illiquid assets)

@TheStalwart One of the coolest things is DeFi is composability, if only because you can compose what previously was represented as a legal contract is hard to compose (e.g. should the newest contract override the previous ones? partially? what's the settlement logic?)

@TheStalwart Fees associated to structured products — by being able to program the incentives around securitized structured products instead of relying on the Matt Levine's of the world to legally make them obey certain payoffs, you can improve capital efficiency/fees by an order of magnitude

@ChainLinkGod Yeah, but this is not a complete model/description. How do I price the insurance for an update to a volatility vs. and update to a price? For an options protocol the former being manipulated causes more damage than the latter and should be more expensive to insure
@TraversaJulian External economic factors seem to be “are there future expectations of fees” though
*include oracles in consensus (or not)

But, it is unclear if @VitalikButerin’s post intends to be a billy pulpit for turning on fees — he kind of implicitly argues for fees for moving oracles to the app layer which, intended or not, is a somewhat controversial move for the Uniswap community, especially today

I do think that $UNI with fees is an excellent staking token, one in which you could imagine an oracle token future expected earnings dictating the cost of manipulation — the higher trading volume markets subsidize security for the less traded markets (unlike TradFi!)

The trade-off between staking lockups vs. fee revenue as the main incentive for truthful data provision is highly underspecified and needs to be understood deeply before embarking on deciding a $UNI vs. $LINK “winner” (could really be a duopoly though)

That being said, $UNI with fees turned on (or even $SUSHI) could be a superior “oracle token” to those of protocols that tie security to consensus or to off-chain networks

I think the proposal lacks a lot of details though, especially relative to competing models

But there is a sense in which @VitalikButerin’s point is that there does need to be a security budget for an on-chain oracle and the question of whether it is a cash flow oracle or not and it’s time value is quite important to the decision to slide oracles from consensus
*rely

At the same time, not having to stake $UNI makes this comparison (that he implicitly makes in the post) quite unclear as the time value of money / discounting is not enforced — you felt too much on the $UNI market cap as collateral

The idea of changes in fees representing latency is something that does occur in normal finance ("theta drag") is not so crazy and maybe more accretive to $UNI than the $LINK 2.0 model which fails to posit an insurance model for bad parameters

Still not clear though

I think that @VitalikButerin making a strong case for $UNI as a somewhat substitute (not complementary) good for $LINK is one of the more surprising valuation+security models of this wild market

But IMO, it isn’t totally insane, fee-wise

@danrobinson @_Dave__White_ @SBF_Alameda Given a set of stopping times, you can compute funding rate using classical methods; this article chooses a set of those and interpolates (but it’s not a different class of payoffs.)
The hard part is enumerating the set of stopping times (which maps to roll over rates), which the authors did by picking a particular set of strategies

@arush @TheStalwart @tomhschmidt @joonian 1. You stake 100 ETH and run a validation node
2. The current monthly staking yield is 10%
3. You borrow 5 ETH against your future staked income (10 ETH in one month)
4. If slashed / don’t earn 10 ETH in a month, you still owe 5 ETH + interest (taken out of your staked deposit)
@arush @TheStalwart @tomhschmidt @joonian This is why I think staking derivatives need to be rebranded vs. the rest of DeFi so that @TheStalwart and others can view them via more traditional lenses

@arush @TheStalwart @tomhschmidt @joonian Staking derivatives are partially undercollateralized, in the traditional sense. The lender loses money if you get slashed / don’t earn as much in block rewards as you’re supposed to within the duration of the loan

@altegaard @KentoInami Hopefully a lot! But you can still see lots of inefficient arb bots that don’t execute trades at the right size (especially on Solana, BSC, Terra), so maybe there are fewer people than you might expect who’ve read them carefully

@altegaard @KentoInami @TheStalwart You can see this on new chains a lot, where arbs basically incrementally trade in increasing size until prices equalized (but in reality, if they solved the convex program correctly, they could’ve done it in one trade)

@altegaard @KentoInami @TheStalwart The other thing that’s extremely important for the CFMM design is their convexity for optimal arbitrage: even a random strategy (basically stochastic gradient descent) to arb prices will converge quickly (unlike, say, arbing LMSR prices)

@altegaard @KentoInami Why are online ads high dimensional? Each ad is a decision tree (male, 30s, SF, reads @TheStalwart) and AMMs were supposed to price “all” decision trees simultaneously even though there might only be liquidity/trading in O(log log |Trees|) trees

For 2 assets, this is overkill

@altegaard @KentoInami There were also lots of impossibility theorems for AMMs from the 2010s; the earliest versions (LMSRs and analogues) were non-convex (even #P-complete) and people assumed they’d never work — but they were wrong in that they only considered high dimensional markets (online ads)

We believe these results open the door, for those quantitative enough, to construct ways for protocols to hedge and insure themselves in a more meaningful way than exists right now

But you're going to have to do more work than that of the idealized model of the paper 🙃

Why would a replication be useful?

If one were underwriting insurance to a lending protocol, you could compute the exposure of the protocol by summing up each outstanding borrow's option exposure 👉 construct a CFMM to securitize exposure
 
👉 Short CFMM to hedge your insurance

Other cool fact buried in the paper: if the idealized model of lending protocols as covered options sellers holds, you can replicate the protocol's exposure with a CFMM!

This means a synthetic asset representing the Compound protocol's exposure can be constructed *statically*

This is why simulating the risk of default in Aave/Compound/Maker is quite difficult — you need to understand correlations induced by EVM execution, user behavior to get precise probabilities (what we do @gauntletnetwork)

OTOH, theoretical tools help provide 1st order intuition!

While Put-Call symmetry is amazingly useful in theory, it  is natural to ask what its limitations / assumptions are. As shown by Carr & Lee, Put-Call symmetry implies that  for stochastic volatility models, price and volatility must be independent (SABR/Heston fine, others bad) https://t.co/7clLw6IExk

Put-Call symmetry lets you reason about the time for a price process S to hit a barrier H and you get *exact* formulas for replications — this is the magic of why in no-arb/no gas cost, we're able to exactly price the value of an @AaveAave or @compoundfinance liquidator's option

What is Put-Call symmetry? If we own a call on Euro-denominated options on an asset, that's equal, in some sense, to owning a set of USD-denominated puts on an asset

What's the ratio calls to puts? The Put-Call symmetry formula above delineates this quantity for many processes

But for something like Black-Scholes, this isn't true — Geometric Brownian Motion + Lévy processes aren't symmetric [they're non-negative!]

BUT: they can be symmetric in a logarithmic sense, where a certain relation holds for all bounded, measurable g 👉 Put-Call Symmetry https://t.co/QcEgTpef4Z

Recall from stats 101: Two paths from a symmetric random walk that are reflections of each other have the same probability (see figure)

For these paths, we can look at hitting times t = {S < H} vs. t = {S > H} and know that they're equal via symmetry — a path-dependent result! https://t.co/BoygiM5xk4

1st: What's a down-and-in option?

DOIC(K, S, H) with strike K, asset price S, barrier H pays off max(S-K, 0) if S < H

This is less than a normal call (S<H condition) & depends on price path (did S[t] ever hit H?)

If American options can't be explicitly priced, how can this?

The paper explicitly connects the option that a liquidator holds to a down-and-in knock-in option
- a: liquidation incentive
- l: ratio of liq threshold to LTV
- p(t0): loan entry price

What’s the upshot of such a hedge?
1. Represent protocol exposure as basket of options
2. Protocol can dynamically buy portfolio insurance to cover/hedge these risks

Insurance funds like @AaveAave safety module and @compoundfinance staking chain are DeFi’s first attempts at (2)

One-touches are notoriously hard to price — they are path-dependent, making normal stochastic calculus methods hard to use

Luckily, Carr and El Karoui invented some tricks — namely Put-Call symmetry — to price these options

Also change of numéraire (Shreve II, Ch9) is used

So what can we do?

In 2011, @arbitragegoth taught me about the *dirtiest* sounding product in FX finance: “one-touch digital options”

These are binary options triggered by the price touching a particular level — which is exactly the type of option a borrower in a protocol has!

Why?
1. @AaveAave and @compoundfinance define liquidatable and default states which are triggered when the price touches a certain limit (vanilla call options don’t do this)

2. Liquidators get paid an incentive — their execution price is different than that of a call https://t.co/hIpqVg71xJ

What does this mean? 

Each loan that a lending protocol issues is *almost* a covered call exposure:
1. Holds collateral 
2. Sold options to the borrower to repurchase collateral
3. Sold options to the liquidator for buy defaulted loans

But it’s not *quite* a covered call

But what’s the risk held by these CFMM lenders?

While you need to do more in-depth fee & slippage simulation analysis for a true assessment (see: @gauntletnetwork), we describe an idealized, no-arbitrage way to hedge the risk held by a CFMM lender using barrier/exotic options

Why? Effectively the convexity of their exposure is determined by the LP share value function except when they’re close to liquidation (Gamma violently changes sign near liquidation) — we quantify the amount this happens for generic portfolio value functions which keeps you safe

We generalize our previous result on replicating market makers and show that *any* bounded convex payoff can be replicated by borrowing against an LP share with a particular curve

The precise bound depends on the choice generalized LTV — important for @AlphaFinanceLab users

Another cool thing: we describe generalized LTVs which show that traditional lending in Aave/Compound can be viewed as a subset of CFMM lending

This suggests that the space of structured products spanned by borrowing against CFMMs is quite massive — does it include all payoffs?

👉🏾 Lending + CFMM protocols like @SushiSwap’s Kashi can provide way better efficiency if they dynamically adjust LTVs in response to price changes and fee accruals

I found this insanely counterintuitive until I wrote the equations — LP shares can be amazing collateral w/ care

We first show how to compare Loan-to-Value (LTV) / collateral factors between borrowing A with B as a collateral vs. borrowing A against an A/B LP pool share 

Turns out, with dynamically adjusted LTVs you can make LP share lending *more* safe than lending of the underlying https://t.co/G6MCb6lia8

One mechanism for improving capital efficiency in CFMM trading is borrowing against LP shares (e.g. @AaveAave, @AlphaFinanceLab, @MakerDAO, @SushiSwap)

How safe is it compared to normal lending?

It took a *long* time for people to formalize what the Replica Trick does, and that too, only in mean-field models [although Sourav Chatterjee proved some crazy result in 2014 about random field models not having replica properties for almost all temperatures, couplings]

One of the most mind-boggling, accidental discoveries by physicists is something called the Replica Trick, where you consider an ensemble of n statistical systems interacting, compute their joint free energy, then take the limit as n -> 0 and claim ”analytic continuation”

So what does this tell you?
1. Staking derivatives are way harder to analyze mathematically, but if you do it, there is waaaay prettier math than the usual "Computer Scientists only know the uniform distribution" type of probability
2. Carry costs will dominate network expansion

5. We also looked at 'carry costs': I lend X units of PoS token vs. I stake X units, borrow cX (c < 1) via derivative — what is Yield(X) - Yield(cX)? We studied this indirectly via looking at how aggressively stakers borrowed against their locked stake (higher == lower carry) https://t.co/eSdIG9Lriz

If you want to learn more about this rather beautiful subject (especially if you like measure theory, functional analysis, and extremal value probability) check out this great tutorial from Cécile Mailler

https://t.co/AkdiD77z2n

b. PoS + Derivatives: Derivative liquidation will mutate the stake distribution evolution — now you have a _random_ stochastic process on stake distributions 

MVPP do this and let us generalize @giuliacfanti, et. al's "concentration of wealth in PoS" results to random measures

4. We found a unique phase transition in the scenario with derivatives that got to use some very oblique math (esp. for people in crypto/quant. fin) — measure-valued Pólya urn processes (MVPP)

Why did we need this?
a. PoS: Pólya urn-esque process (sample from stake distribution)

3. Our model focused on endogenous staking derivatives (built into the protocol) vs. exogenous (like Lido) — technically the latter is more secure, but any lending rate competition provided by stakers is better than nothing

https://t.co/kkpTGa3hf2

2. Adding derivatives and optimizing the portfolios makes things get a lot more complicated (akin to the jump from 2-SAT to 3-SAT) because you implicitly allow smaller stakers to get 'more equal' opportunity to borrowing from the protocol ▶️ define desired network properties https://t.co/iWaw5RSsGK

1. If you assume participants are mean-variance portfolio optimizers (as opposed to 'honest'), then without derivatives, you can have staking dominate lending

Formally, we proved a submartingale-supermartingale phase transition for when this happened and justified it with sims https://t.co/qpXyhgtB36

And I will say that I’m excited to see @arbitrum’s code for this – their research + that of @vegaprotocol is definitely the closest to making a convincing argument for fair sequencing chains

Current fair ordering code reminds me of SNARK code right after the 2012 Gentry paper came out — raw, full of potential, but should be miles away from billions of dollars of assets until compositional guarantees are proven in theory and production

Summary: fair ordering protocols are a real solution, but they’re far from perfect (both theoretically and in production code). MEV auctions are much less technically difficult and don’t worsen UX as much (which is why I took offense to @AriJuels usage of "theft")
MEV auctions are a lot easier to reason about, especially with regards to how they compose with consensus and even then, one has to be diligent and careful with practical implementations

Back to the main narrative: this complexity means that we don’t know how well these fair ordering protocols compose with main consensus except in synchronous BFT settings. This is bad for practical Blockchains — not impossible, but will need a helluva lot of engineering

Aside: I once spent an afternoon trying to map the permutation matching in fair ordering protocols to maximal matchings on bipartite Ramanujan graphs (which admit decompositions by interlacing symmetric polynomials), but got stuck and got why Kadison-Singer was *really* hard

3. Many of the fair order protocols are quite complex with good reason: they’re solving a much more difficult combinatorial problem of optimal ordering of interlacing permutations (one for block ordering and one for txn ordering)

order matters ➡️ can’t do greedy maximal matching https://t.co/erlo7CL9OM

All of the fair ordering solutions are oblivious to transaction value / content and only care about consistency of a distributed priority queue vs users expressed preferences/DSIC-style guarantees 

Is this better? I’m not sure — user intent now relies on latency more than before

2. MEV Auctions have 1 nice property: they separate the Veblen good-like bidders (liquidators/arbs) from “daily” txns and guarantee price ordering as a function of transaction _value_ is preferred if auction is appropriately ε-close to DSIC (@suryabakshi has more precise conds.)

Recent papers from @algo_class and Joachim Neu show lower bounds on these latencies and it is very unclear if the practical implementations even come close to saturating these bounds (Kelkar, et. al get to weaker bounds in their paper) https://t.co/mGPus27sdi

Why added latency?

Theoretical  (@vegaprotocol’s Wendy) and practical protocols (@valardragon) add a >= 1 block commit-reveal from validators OR added rounds of BFT-style message passing. Griefing vectors (DDoS-esque) are abundant + provable models have weak synchrony guarantees

This is a good thread about the MEV War of 2021™️

One thing I will say is that most of the fair methodologies have a downsides themselves:
1. Added latency
2. Lack of guarantees about economic price ordering
3. Extremely unproven in production (similar to ZKPs in 2012)

@ArthurB In you start in the continuous case the options representation is almost trivial (expanding in ReLUs via the representer theorem, add in boundary condition at 0). But I think it's more interesting to consider how the discrete OB converges to the continuous case

@ArthurB Yes, but my point was that:
a. The way you take the limit depends on the order arrival process
b. The distribution on positive functions depends on this limit 
c. The Greeks of options you sell depend on this limit

Hence the non-uniqueness (which is why it isn't a red herring)
@ArthurB This is encoded in how you take the limit, which dictates what you converge to and bounds on error

@ArthurB The choice of f_n will dictate the distribution of observed OB (and my point is more that the representation of the limit distibution might be more concise with f_n OB_n vs. g_n OB'_n in that |f_n OB_n - OB| = o(|g_n OB'_n|)

@ArthurB The wavelet point was an analogy for rate of convergence to the limit shape. If we view an order book as a random function OB : R_+ -> R_+ taken as the limit of OB_n : R_+ -> N and we look at limits f_n(tick size) OB_n with f_n = o(1), then what process do we get?

@ArthurB Taking the limit as 1/sqrt(tick size) vs. taking the limit as 1/tick size^3/2 will give you different limit order books because the finite tick size arrival time process is atomic (e.g. limit of sums of Poissons / level)
@JeremyRubin Yeah queue position / cancellation is a weird effect BUT exists in exotic options like barriers and lookbacks

@JeremyRubin In some ways yes, although it's not clear to order flow sellers how their flow maps to changes in the volatility surface 

Also queue position (as you note in your point re: cancellation) affects implied strike by order placement subtly

One of the cool things is that there is not a unique best "continuous order book limit" 

In the same way that expanding a smooth enough function in a wavelet basis has exponentially faster convergence than a polynomial basis, the same applies here

There's a sect of the market microstructure literature that views placing a limit order as selling an option to the market at a strike in between the tick sizes you're bidding at 

Selling call option => negative Gamma => IL 😇 

Continuous limits of OBs will be fun

What does this say about the future of CFMMs?

I'm going to make a claim:

ZKP compilers (@StarkWareLtd's Cairo, @the_matter_labs's Zinc, etc.) are going to be incredibly valuable technologies but the first ZKP compiler that also compiles private CFMMs is worth $100s of Bs

This is great, but can we _actually_ compute anything with this?

Yes! We give explicit curves for *statically* replicated covered options positions (covered calls, protective puts) which are popular on @realMatrixport and coming to DeFi via players like @ribbonfinance

One cool thing about these conditions is that they have clear economic interpretations:
- Concavity: Impermanent Loss exists
- Nonnegative: LP share value >= 0
- Nondecreasing: Coin prices go up doesn't hurt LP val
- 1-homogeneous: Choice of numéraire doesn't matter https://t.co/rB8L8wrTcb

By classifying the necessary and sufficient conditions for a payoff function (e.g. hockey stick payoff of an option), one is able to 'compile' or 'solve for' a CFMM curve that leads to that payoff

This can be used to compile payoffs (options, ...) to e.g. PSD quadratics (Uni V3) https://t.co/XI9FiNITQD

Previously, @GuilleAngeris and I proved the value of an LP share is tied to the Fenchel (convex) dual of the CFMM curve

Now we are able to classify *all* curves that give valid, non-manipulable CFMMs — think of this as the 'classification theorem of finite groups' but for CFMMs

In TradFi, static replication methods completely changed the hedging landscape

One of the 1st papers I read in quant finance was @EmanuelDerman's tome on static options replication, which made me realize the power of avoiding dynamic rebalancing

For instance, it seems like there should be some analogue of a field extension for simulations: given a simulation and black box access to a function of complexity f(n), the set of recursively approximable objects grows by a factor of f(n)^k

So what is the set of computational “simulacra”? Is there an algebra for things that can be approximated via recursive simulations? Relationships between recursive ZKP constructions suggest there might be some algebraic relations between recursively simulable systems
On the other hand, it is clear that other things don’t work — I’m not simulating a QMA algorithm with black box access to a probabilistic poly time Turing Machine

While this seems woefully underspecified, there are some ways in which it’s true:

Each real number is defined as an equivalence class of Cauchy sequences, I can simulate sequences of up to length N+1 given oracle access to sequences of length N

If you could recursively run simulations within other simulations, could you approximate a simulacra?

When pitched on private CFMMs, be careful! They're likely leaking information via side-channels (even if a ZKP is used!) 

We’re not the 1st to point this out — @barrywhitehat  wrote heuristic arguments that inspired us to prove some theorems 💪

https://t.co/haNaBF43IG

So what does this mean?

1. Privacy in CFMMs needs either a) randomness or b) batching

2. Why? These break uniqueness — a batch might have k orders but how do I know how to uniquely map k addresses to k orders?

Differential privacy techniques might also help (cc @gautamkamath) https://t.co/I5gaeke2yk

Intuition:

1. Convexity crucial for CFMMs — prior work shows this makes optimal arbitrage ‘easy’

2. BUT: also guarantees uniqueness of price <> trade sizes (c.f. strict convex = unique global minima)

@guilleangeris divined a proof using a separating hyperplane theorem https://t.co/1vT0cFujpN

If you can map (last_address_of_trade, price) to (qty_traded), then you have deanonymized a private CFMM, sending @DegenSpartan into hiding as his α leaks are front-run

This paper provides a formal proof showing the existence + *uniqueness* of such a map for many CFMMs https://t.co/AJLDRlVYFv

One crucial fact about CFMMs like @Uniswap, @BalancerLabs, @SushiSwap, and @CurveFinance: they need to publicly display prices (otherwise no one will trade 📈)

But by doing this, it is natural to ask: If I observing prices, can I infer the quantities traded by individual users? https://t.co/S7IRAtPMmn

People talk about keeping Sauron (aka @ASvanevik / @nansen_ai) from knowing how much 🍣 degenspartan.eth traded for 🍠

Most attempts use Zero Knowledge Proofs (ZKPs) to privately call the trade function

This should hide your escape from the omakase — but is this airtight 💦? https://t.co/05NoWVJceP

I guess I really mean:

AM = Capital(X_1, Y_1)  + ... +  Capital(X_n, Y_n) ≈ E[Capital(X_1, Y_1) + ... + Capital(X_k, Y_k)]

where we assume WLOG

Capital(X_1, Y_1) > Capital(X_2, Y_2) > ...

Notation:
- TAM: Total capital added to the set of all pairs
- Capital(X, Y): Maximum capital (measured in numéraire) allocated to pair (X, Y) during asset price cycle

Galaxy Brain Question: Is there a total ordering on the set of (X, Y) pairs such that:

1. Pr[Capital(X_n, Y_n) > TAM/n] = O(e^-kn)
2. TAM = Capital(X_1, Y_1)  + ... +  Capital(X_n, Y_n) = E[Capital(X_1, Y_1) + ... + Capital(X_k, Y_k)]

when k = Θ(log n)?

@dankrad @aeyakovenko @bcmakes Once you model PoW’s ecosystem as three distinct but correlated markets vs. one big market (staking), then it becomes clear they cannot be the same for statistical reasons

@Leorzhang has a good post on assessing the mining market’s component correlations via derivatives

@dankrad @aeyakovenko @bcmakes Staking yield and investment in mining are extremely disjoint and unlikely to have convergent yields
1. Highly fragmented, regulated market (e.g. look at Texas grid failure)
2. Other is open Eurodollar-like bond market 

Historically yields are correlated but never converge!

@dankrad @aeyakovenko @bcmakes One day, in the future, I hope that cryptographers are forced to learn some quant. finance, measure-theoretic probability theory, and statistics 😇

I feel like counter examples in statistics should be guiding your intuition, not “too complex, but might be real though”

@dankrad @aeyakovenko @bcmakes Even if it does, it’s higher dimensional because you have to consider:
1. Yields on hash power (via futures)
2. Yields on energy derivatives
3. Yields on PoW asset directly
vs. just aggregated yield on PoS token

Statistically disjoint, e.g. https://t.co/CndrWLJR16

@dankrad @aeyakovenko @bcmakes This disjoint nature of the locked resource market (energy, hash) from the token’s market (market for PoW currency) vs. only having a single market for locked resource and token (PoS) is the *defining* feature of the security model difference

@dankrad @aeyakovenko @bcmakes How do you incorporate the “whole world” in PoW modeling? It’s very hard to jointly model the *entire* energy market, the hash power market (correlated but not the same) and the asset’s market whereas it is easy to model all markets where you trade PoS token T (see 2)

@dankrad @aeyakovenko @bcmakes 1. Arbitrary times of validator entry (need to enter on epoch boundary)
2. Ability to handle high money velocity 
https://t.co/yOgphpPF9t
3. Ability to resist lending attacks
https://t.co/jqkMX3nAsb

These are not insurmountable for UX — but show diff. security model!

@dankrad @aeyakovenko @bcmakes My real point is “cargo cult semi-science” is abundant in this field and it’s all of our jobs to avoid the negatives of such systems by being precise when making such claims  https://t.co/d6y03isd7t

@aeyakovenko @bcmakes Incomparable! PoS and PoW have non-comparable security models, sadly

@SBF_Alameda @GuilleAngeris @spreekaway @ArthurB @danrobinson @alexhevans I’m not arguing for logarithmic measurements, but instead a simple observation that you often end up sublinear when you add in practical constraints that are you realized

@SBF_Alameda @GuilleAngeris @spreekaway @ArthurB @danrobinson @alexhevans But the constraints you engender in practice (liquidity constraints, observed correlations / seasonality) turn “linear” into “linear with constraints” which can be... very different!
@SBF_Alameda @GuilleAngeris @spreekaway @ArthurB @danrobinson @alexhevans Because it effects the discounted expectation E[e^(-\int_0^t r(s) ds Price(t)]

@SBF_Alameda @GuilleAngeris @spreekaway @ArthurB @danrobinson @alexhevans In practice, you don’t know the expectation operator to make it linear — you take a simple model and add in features and constraints based on priors, but that makes it non-linear since you’re never computing in the “true” expectation operator

@SBF_Alameda @GuilleAngeris @spreekaway @ArthurB @danrobinson @alexhevans Right, but interest rate volatility factors into your expectation operator and potentially does as a constraint

Worst-case volatility corrections != average case, and for some markets you do one and not the other

@SBF_Alameda @GuilleAngeris @spreekaway @ArthurB @danrobinson @alexhevans A trader adds in these liquidity constraints, especially ones due to natural timing issues, as constraints that turn a linear expectation into a constraint optimization problem — not the same

tl;dr: Given the immense interest in optimal control in DeFi, we found a way to rephrase the 'do you need fees? how much?' problem for AMMs in terms of a RL-like Bellman equation

Perhaps some of the predictions @htkao and I made will come true https://t.co/5DsW2Yh6wG

December: Rough proof that the zero-fee phase transition from Martin/Dave is real, but is better viewed via the control theory lens

January: Rewrite proof in Reinforcement Learning language — describe Bellman equation for LP returns w/ fees

Timeline 🕰️

October: @alexhevans had a genius idea of viewing LP returns from the perspective of a stochastic process on weights

November: @MartinTassy / @_Dave__White_ result out, we were confused as to why the proof was so specific to Uniswap

By the way, @MartinTassy's discovery of the '0 fee phase transition' looks a lot more like conventional transitions in 1-dimension from the optimal control lens

This paper shows that it is more of a 2nd order transition than a 1st order one for @BalancerLabs/@UniswapProtocol https://t.co/RnDqRcsB4B

In Uniswap, you can replicate the volatile weights by adding and removing liquidity around orders (like sandwich attacks), which is _effectively_ the same as quoting a price schedule in an order book

c.f. @ProfessorJEY's nice little note

https://t.co/dNJo96VMCw

This paper is short and sweet, but gets to the heart of the debate between Dan & SBF: Why does utility matter?

Results intimate:
- When weights are very volatility you prefer linear
- When weights are static, you prefer logarithmic

Volatile weights ~ MMs frequently quoting

Instead of looking at profits as a function of fees, drift, vol, we look at weights (controlled by arbitrageurs)

This gives you a Bellman equation (like those in reinforcement learning!) that only depends on your utility function indirectly (via ϕ)

2-assets: Solved w/ Wronskian https://t.co/kzcJDu6h8i

Trad. Optimal Control: Robot/program has 100% deterministic control over the intervention (e.g. moving robot arm)

LP vs. Arbs: Stochastic control plus fees add a wrinkle — the fee interval. Arbs can never exactly get to w* because of fees, yet Martin/Dave show LPs are still 🤑🤑 https://t.co/kQcbWfq1wJ
