@krzhang There are two opposing forces:
1. Optimized Capital Efficiency requires a complex partition (e.g. liquidation conditions)
2. Safety requires a simple one (e.g. easy to insure via options/convex sets)

There’s a “surface tension” between these that must be growing

@krzhang There’s a sense in which it’s the same though: if I have a closed financial system and I add an arbitrary partition with constraint, I end up needing derivs/insurance to guarantee liquidity transfer across the partition

In memetic investing, price/volume/book changes are effectively *causal*, which means that traditional signal analysis needs to include 'long-range' momentum terms that include 'counterfactual regret'-like terms to describe long-range causal behavior

Independence of rollouts is key to a lot of optimization algorithms (e.g. batch gradient descent methods) and for error/confidence interval estimation (e.g. jackknife / bootstrap estimation)

But it *doesn't* hold whatsoever for memetically traded assets

In quant trading, you tend to look at signals over rollouts (akin to playouts in reinforcement learning) *assuming* that the rollouts are independent samples

This means y = Ax fit on (x1, y1), ... (xn, yn) assumes (x1, y1) doesn't increase/decrease the probability of (xn, yn)

One of the core tenets of 'memetic' investing that I had to disabuse myself of after leaving HFT is:

For some assets (Tesla, Bitcoin, Moderna), market price, book depth, and volume are basically PR for the next set of buyers

'momentum' in quant trading does *not* include this

By the way, what do I mean by hysteresis?

Autocorrelation: C(t, t', drift) = E[(P(t)-P(t'))(P(t)-P(t') | drift]/E[P(t)|drift]E[P(t')|drift]

Hitting time: τ(ε, drift) = inf({t : ∃ t > 0 s.t. C(t,t',drift) < ε})

Drift: μ

Then you get this when you vary drift from 0 to x to 0 https://t.co/PAXVBqLHmG

Where else in STEM do you see similar hysteresis-laden phase transitions?

Simplest examples are:
1. Spin Glasses
2. Random Field Ising Model
3. Queueing processes with memory (generalization of M/M/k)
4. Control Theory + Economics (below)

https://t.co/X1FLfCURo7

Which ones map best to crypto? Who knows! 

I am sure that there is *a* phase transition, although it isn't clear which direction is worse, especially without much data

Data from the spate of algorithmic stablecoin launches will descirbe the minimal model for hysteresis

This suggests a deeper connection between no-arbitrage theorems and computational complexity — not so different than QFT and gravity having a deep duality 

Each type of leverage is a different type of “inefficient market” which can only be used to run certain programs

The subtle differences between the flash loans complexity class FL (with halting ∈ FL) and leverage over forks in final (non-branching polynomial) and non-final (branching polynomial) suggests that we can subdivide and filter P and NP based on the types of leverage allowed

Next: leverage interlaces with consensus protocols

Non-flash leverage taken before a fork (in non-final protocols) gets to be used “twice” until consensus agrees on a fork

The class of on-chain programs that use leverage are thus branching (e.g. NC) https://t.co/w9ZUf5LP1J

Flash loans take a computation and execute it in a way such that we halt if we pass a leverage recursion depth limit

Flash loans’ ability to precisely halt means that the programs executable by a flash loan must be in a complexity class where the halting problem is computable

On-chain leverage is a bounded recursive computation

One applies the leverage operation recursively up before the computation halts (liquidation)

Interlacing this with other operations is makes full FV in DeFi impossible

@Galois_Capital Parallelizability is effectively the geometric condition that for any element x, there exists a path between x and x^-1 such that parallel transport with the Levi-Civita connection is possible 

This is *required* to construct inverses
@Galois_Capital *So there is not..
@Galois_Capital So it there is not division algebra for 16-dimensions *precisely* because the 15 dimensional sphere (which would be the group of units of the division algebra) is not parallelizable

@Galois_Capital The last part is used to the Lie Algebra (= tangent space at fixed point) generated by a parallelizable manifold is a division algebra

The one dimensional lower spheres are the group of units for the algebras (which are needed for division to be well-defined)
@Galois_Capital Yes, you can use the reduced K group of a sphere to see this

The final post (and the release of the paper) will show how curvature and yield farming incentives (especially pool 2!) interact

We'll illustrate the optimization problem for *optimally* choosing farming rewards for pool 2

Designing dynamic update rules will inevitably be tied to designing the correct gradient flow that adjusts a CFMM's curvature

Given the centuries of work in differential geometry on such flows, it is inevitable that we will see them (and control theory) interacting with CFMMs

So what does this mean for the future of CFMM design?
1. Curvature is dual to adverse selection (e.g. stablecoin-stablecoin trades aren't v. adverse, so you don't need much curvature)
2. Dynamic updates to a CFMM, either by an oracle or endogenously, need to account for shape

This shows that protective CFMMs like @BreederDodo and any CFMM @hosseeb says needs an oracle simply by reducing LP adverse selection by adjusting curvature

But this also intimates you can do this endogenously *without* an oracle if you are willing to store more on-chain state

1. We model roundtrip trades: This is when an 🦍 makes a trade but ends up being wrong, this leads to 🐳, 🧙 profits

2. Our game more carefully connects impermanent loss to the shape of the CFMM as we explicitly consider the effects of changes in marginal price on LP share value https://t.co/AnMAJR8IoM

Inspired by Jun Aoyogi's work on Uniswap adverse selection, we generalized his results to @CurveFinance & more

Similar to Jun, we construct a game between LPs 🐳, informed traders 🦍, & arbs 🧙 to find an equilibrium condition

But our game is different in a couple key ways 🔮

These results generalize Glosten & Milgrom (1984), Kyle (1985) to arbitrary CFMMs

This seminal work shows the shape of the order book represents the amount of adverse selection a market maker feels, leading to strategies where they remove liquidity to avoid adverse selection https://t.co/yA105eJxsb

Post 1 tl;dr: Curvature controls pool price stability

Post 2: Curvature *directly* controls:
- LP profits when asset pairs are mean reverting 
- ∃ a magic formula relating LP profit to adverse selection (probability α of LP realizing IL), curvature, and fees for *any* CFMM! https://t.co/NqxkQ5fpUb

Can we recover the optimal time-dependent CFMM given a price process? 🧐

We show (and will illustrate in the following posts) that curvature, fees, and adverse selection are tightly related and you can't change one without affecting the others

A lot of this work was inspired by looking at new, flat curves from @BreederDodo, @MonteCarloDEX, & @yield https://t.co/JxtfWfurxI

There's a trade-off surface:
- Low curvature: large trade size for traders 📈, adverse selection for LPs 📉
-  High curvature: large impact cost for traders 📉, LPs are profitable 📈

Prior thoughts on CFMMs aimed to try to optimize fees alone but..

https://t.co/hOq6KheIDs

When we dug into this a little more, it became clear that Gaussian curvature controls a lot of facets of CFMMs:

1. Price synchronization between two CFMMs
2. Adverse Selection for LP returns
3. Price stability
4. Optimal incentives for yield farming

@notyourkeys @fabdaRice @iamDCinvestor @drakefjustin @dannyryan @UMAprotocol @yield Next suppose that the bias is 10% on average but the variance of this bias is 20% — you could have *less* of a chance of winning the block because your grinding algorithm isn't exactly. How much do you spend? How much less is it than the former case?

@notyourkeys @fabdaRice @iamDCinvestor @drakefjustin @dannyryan Suppose there's an oracle update at height 1000 you want to front run for some period event (e.g. expiry in @UMAprotocol / @yield) and it's worth $100m to you. You can spend $10k/hour on compute to bias yourself to a 10% more likelihood of winning it. How much do you spend?
Is this a feature or a bug? 🧐

@fabdaRice @iamDCinvestor @drakefjustin @dannyryan A VDF limits your ability to manipulate such a commit since the arrival time of the next piece of data you need to either forward or include in a block has a higher enough variance that grinding will cost you more (in time and compute) than the value of the improved bias

@fabdaRice @iamDCinvestor @drakefjustin @dannyryan Manipulating previous commits is one way to grind to force a PRNG (like a VRF) to select you with some bias b in (0, 1) such that your probability of being selected is (1+b) * validators_stake/total_stake

In a lot of protocols, previous commits are hashed into the next VRF draw

@fabdaRice @iamDCinvestor @drakefjustin @dannyryan Right, one of the main reasons for wanting a VDF in consensus is to ensure that validators don’t know they’re chosen in advance

I like Dan Boneh’s single secret leader election paper as a good description of how to reduce MEV
@fabdaRice @iamDCinvestor @drakefjustin @dannyryan So you’ll only have dt = time_until_next_slot - time_bp_is_selected as the time to compute the optimal transaction to insert + pick an ordering.

@fabdaRice @iamDCinvestor @drakefjustin @dannyryan But in order to do this, we actually need to be the producer at the correct block height. If there is sufficiently hard to bias randomness (especially with regards to the expected time until next block), it is basically impossible to commit to an MEV transaction ahead of time

@fabdaRice @iamDCinvestor @drakefjustin @dannyryan Suppose we know an oracle update occurs on block height h

How do we know if we are the block producer for height h?
PoW: Don’t know
PoS: Sometimes know (Tezos, etc.), sometimes don’t (if a VDF or DKG+VRF is used

If we are the producer at h, we can [front,back]run the update

@fabdaRice @iamDCinvestor @drakefjustin @dannyryan Yes, but they have to solve a few problems:
1. Figure out the transaction they can place with maximum PNL
2. Figure out if they are winning correct block for this arb

2) is mitigated (for the most part) by VDFs but 1) is extremely expensive

You’re not running Gurobi in 6s!

@fabdaRice @iamDCinvestor @drakefjustin @dannyryan One natural question is why I say #P complete; see this ethresearch post for an example of how to think about what an optimal price gas bid for an MEV auction is

https://t.co/YvfnAu3yob

@fabdaRice @iamDCinvestor @drakefjustin @dannyryan Err, yes. I meant the complexity of choosing the optimal ordering is very high (potentially #P-complete) so an arbitrageur with less time to compute their gas price and sequences of txns to send will have to make more approximations (= less expected MEV for proposers)

@fabdaRice @iamDCinvestor @drakefjustin @dannyryan Yeah, I agree the statistical accuracy vs. computational complexity trade-off of finding the optimal MEV ordering is harder with shorter block times but improved with higher throughout (can take more shots on the same arb opportunity)

3. Do you really want locally 5-fold symmetry? I think the fact that transaction orderings now have this local free action of S_5 on them would make it hard to avoid MEV on segments of 5 txns or less

2. (cont.) It is possible that prefixes of tx ordering overlap an arbitrary amount, so there isn’t as much transaction ordering entropy as there is from cryptographic graph traversals (e.g. expander graph walks in supersingular isogeny signatures, lattice based crypto)

2. If you want to anonymize a transaction graph by using a lattice with dense spectra (like the Penrose tiling) to define a DAG, note that you aren’t guaranteed that there isn’t *any* local structure that an adversary can find — only that no tx ordering will be unique

As much as I love the Penrose tiling and long-range order (I used to do glass research!), this seems like a terrible idea

1. Diverge correlation times/lengths means time to verify of a single transaction’s validity could take way longer than block propagation

😬😬😬
The proofs are pretty easy to follow and only require basic calculus, so if you want to understand rugpulls and adverse selection, check this out

There’s also a kind of curious stability result that is vaguely reminiscent of “rugpull” dynamics: there’s only a stable equilibrium when there are < 4 LPs, if there’s more you have sharp edge equilibria that you can oscillate between (akin to the “last LP holds the bag”) https://t.co/xWbqbU3qBv

This effectively looks at a mean-field, agent-based model of:
1. Noise traders
2. Informed traders
3. Strategic LPs

@maurelian_ @CurveFinance When I say 'derivatives' here, I mean in the calculus sense. 

Why? 

Abstract trading mechanism: ∃ invariant f such that f holds before/after trade

f(Liquidity, trade) = f(Liquitidity - trade, 0)

LOB: divergence constraint (flows in = stocks out)
CFMM: f stays on a level set

@maurelian_ Not quite! Right now, we have CFMMs that have simple invariants (e.g. most complex is @CurveFinance, a conic combination of a linear and inverse function), but as we find more o(N) space/time trading mechanisms for N trades, we will have to compute a lot more derivatives on-chain

All-in-all 'univalent' was a good name for a single-issue, quorum-fighting party because:

1. Discrete random voting processes w/ thresholds can look like spin glass models whose boundary curves obey SLE
2. Injectivity is a good property for a singly issue political party

These boundary curves of discrete statistical mechanics systems also show up in voting theory (especially w/ quorums!)

Example: A paper by my brother @UthsavC on 'filter bubbles' that occur in voting systems that has 'percolation' transitions like SLE

https://t.co/kLg4WV7gIM

Conformal maps show up a bunch in everyday geometry:
- Computing the area of the Mandelbrot set
- Generating fractal art

More surprisingly: you can generate univalent solutions to such a differential equation by simulating discrete configurations and looking at boundary curves https://t.co/RV9XZ7etM8

de Branges proved the conjecture in 1985 which paved the way for Schramm-Loewner evolution (SLE) — a way to stochastically sample conformal maps on the plane

This yields a one-param. family of univalent conformal maps

But what does this have to do with voting theory? https://t.co/75wNNIsfmj

1910s: Bieberbach conjecture tried to classify the set of conformal mappings of unit disk |z| < 1
to the plane

Riemann: 1-1 map between univalent fns and sets conformally equivalent to the disk

Bieberbach conjecture: conformal map that 'stretches' the disk most is Koebe (below) https://t.co/7ms6QJsnbI

Why?

1. Means 'unpaired chromosome/electron' in biology and chemistry — party needs to be paired in order to meet quorum

2. Univalent functions are injective complex functions (e.g. 1-to-1, good for a single issue platform)

BUT they also make pretty pictures of conformal maps!

I ran through the obvious options:
univalent

unital

@PVienhage @CMEGroup The atomicity of the CFMM trade (e.g. executing a continuous portfolio buy in a single atomic transaction) means your precision of control over theta is better than trying to replicate over many order books (causing impact -> increase gamma -> worsen corr(gamma, theta) -> repeat

@PVienhage @CMEGroup Having the ability to do the latter with high precision is actually quite hard versus having the market price the basket of options via creation-redemption arb

@nethermindeth @DistStateAndMe @mathsguy @GinaRubino_ Why partial? Consider the ordering on tuples (x0, y0) > (x1, y1) did x0 > x1 and y0 > y1. The function x + y is monotone increasing but x - y isn’t (compare it at p = (3, 5) > q = (3, -5))

Partial lets you extend to multiple dimensions vs. total

@nethermindeth @DistStateAndMe @mathsguy @GinaRubino_ Yeah, only thing you need is a partial ordering (e.g. a mapping p: X x X -> {0, 1, -1} where p(x, y) is 1 if x > y, -1 if x < y, and 0 if not comparable) to define monotonicity

Once you have a partial order, you’re monotone increasing (dec.) if p(x, y) = 1 (-1) => f(x) > f(y)

This was a bit of an erudite rant that voyaged through math finance, functional analysis, and thinking about DeFi state transitions, so maybe a little too ambitious for a tweet storm 🙃

This is a bit of a hairy conjecture to try to prove — I've implicitly argued that the set of state transitions from portfolio to portfolio are representable by invertible operators

But: EVM guarantees this for a lot of DeFi contracts (esp. LP shares, lending) so...

This extends to more than LP shares: Any state evolution of a DeFi protocol S1, S2, ... Sn, ... represents evolution of a bounded state transition operator A on 𝔅:

S_i = A^i S1

Why can I assume linear? Choose vN algebra to be smallest one that 1-1 maps trajs. to operators

Why do we need to think of vN algebras?

Non-commutativity: Example above shows that route a), route b) are valued differently AND represented by different pairs of operators (Buy, Sell)

How much these operators don't commute represents the expected price difference for C shares

But computations in DeFi are bounded — both in gas and in compute capacity (e.g. min. liquidity per Uniswap LP share, max liquidity as a function of uint256)

von Neumann algebras are simplest, non-trivial bounded C* algebras

Conjecture: LP share trajectories == vN algebra

What is the space of operators of a Banach space? A C*-algebra

n-dimensional Banach Space: Set of operators is the set of invertible matrices, denoted GL(n, ℝ)

C*-algebras ≈ lim n→∞ GL(n, ℝ) giving linear operators on ∞-dim. function space

https://t.co/feRWRBCkhL

This intimates that we can classify route a) vs. route b) via the maps 𝔅 → 𝔅 that yield routes a and b

⇒ Set of all operators that map 1 RV to another represent the set of all possible LP share price evolutions 

⇒ Possible LP traj. == operators on a Banach space

If unleveraged, this is not true (we can buy or sell as much as possible, but won't be liquidated even though we have huge impermanent loss / negative gamma)

∴ Operators evolving LP share price as a map 𝔅 → 𝔅 are different for route a) [leveraged] vs. route b) [unlev.]

After trade for B to A takes place, the LP share value changes — how?

Operators: Buy : 𝔅 → 𝔅, Sell : 𝔅 → 𝔅 map LP share price (P1, P2 price) as a func. of qtys of tokens A, B

If leveraged, Buy iterated x times will trigger a liquidation if LP share is oracle for lender

Set of RVs on a measurable space is a normed function space

Fundamental theorem of no-arb. assumes function space of derivative securities is complete (Banach space)

∴ LP share under no-arb. must be an element of a Banach space 𝔅, trades map RV in 𝔅 to a new RV in 𝔅

Recall: LP share value is a random variable (RV) dependent on the reserve quantities of A and B (see paper)

The routes a) and b) that we take give us two portfolios with different portfolio values:

P1: long LP share, short B
P2: long LP share

https://t.co/h0zFfgLhzP

If ∃ ∞ liquidity, 4.9 C generated by a) would be the same as 4.9 C generated by b) [a form of the EMH]

But there's not, so routes a) and b) shares will differ in value

But: what is the size of this difference? How do we quantify this?

von Neumann algebras show up here!

Normal Finance: I don't know that you got leverage to mint 4.9 C, I just see you posting 4.9 A, 4.9 B on an order book

DeFi: I know leverage ratio, how you got leverage, and how you mint an LP stake

Q: What should the value of 4.9 C be for route a) be vs. route b)?

Portfolio P1: Go to Aave/Compound (lender) and borrow A collateralized with B

P2: Go to lender borrow B collat. with A

Suppose I start with 10 units of A and want to mint C shares

Two routes to get C:
a. Borrow 4.9 B against 5 A, mint 4.9 C
b. Sell 5 A for 4.9 B, mint 4.9 C

For what it’s worth: I’m not saying that value functions are smooth, but like a lot of machine learning, I’m trying to gain intuition by thinking of what the world looks like *if* adversaries value functions *happened to be* smooth

Local measurements likely can’t tell you the answer — one need only look to Morse theory for simple yet impractical counter examples

So who can interpolate the extremes and be the Hunter S. Thompson of this market?

🧐🧐🧐

But: All of this depends on knowledge of your value function.

Much of online and reinforcement learning assumes you don’t know it or learn it along the way

Philosophical question: can you ever know if a market favors condition number or max curvature optimization from data?

But in crypto, interpolating between “condition number maximizer” and “highest eigenval.” maximizer is possible and market condition dependent 

DeFi, for better or worse, is better for condition number optimizers

VC: need max eigenval. of value function to optimized

Things like the Tracy-Widom law force you to chase fat tails, terrible Sharpe, and anomalous portfolio construction

Trader: need max and min eigenval. of value fn. to be "close" (low condition number) because of regret minimization between your worst and best case outcomes

If your value function is smooth, this gives uniform bounds on the max/min eigenval. of hessian of your val. function

The VC vs. trader “war” of crypto is reminiscent of the previous talent “war” between HFT and online ads: All of these boil down to latency vs. bandwidth trade-offs where "event-driven" investing depends on the condition number of a participants' value function

@Haoskionchain @alexhevans @BalancerLabs @AaveAave Is this optimal? No! Geometric means are particularly bad for sharp changes — think about a polynomial approximating the Weierstrass function — but it shows that CFMMs with local changes replicate very complicated positions

@Haoskionchain Sure! This theorem from @alexhevans shows that any *unlevered* derivative payoff (e.g. convolution of a strike density with price surface) can be replicated by @BalancerLabs LP shares with continuously adjusted weights 

You can get levered payoffs by lending these on @AaveAave https://t.co/rI1FFG62qh
I feel like all of the stochastic calculus and weird convolutions of strike densities that you see in math finance books is *actually* possible in DeFi, in a way that is hard to do in normal finance

Traditional finance has focused on swaps as
a. In-kind (e.g. interest for interest)
b. Purely Synthetic (e.g. variance swaps, VIX)

DeFi let's you combine the two — in-kind on one side in exchange for synthetic on the other

Impossible to do this without non-custodial assets!

∴ LP staking is equivalent to collateralizing a leg of an interest rate swap with future expected cash flows from an options portfolio

This is actually *really* hard to execute in normal finance — especially because the CFMM replication is a continuous combination of strikes

The number of traditional finance chads (e.g. @arbitragegoth) asking me questions about DeFi LP staking is 📈📈 📈

Here's what it is:
1. @synthetix_io / @kaiynne pioneered paying users for liquidity by staking CFMM LP shares
2. CFMM LP shares replicate options portfolios

@hasufl It's not a traditional frequentist hypothesis test, but it at least ensures that people don't try to game which mechanism gets their capital (via the uniform randomness) and uses the ZK commit/reveal on withdraw to ensure that people are incentivized to do a one-shot allocation

@hasufl Randomized A/B test: root contract uniformly draws a random number c in [0, 1] and puts c * deposit_size in mechanism 1 and (1-c) * deposit_size in mechanism 2.

You can also make a ZK commit/reveal to balances so that the user doesn't know c until they withdraw

*when the $PASTA is worth 0

What does this tell you? 

Analyze the math behind these Ponzis... if you can map it to a classical combinatorial game (e.g. Nim) you probably are getting owned by the contract creator 🙃🙃🙃

How do you model this?

Above framework looks at the hitting time of a discrete random walk to reaching zero given

a) initial $PASTA supply
b) initial $PASTA distribution

The pairwise matching ex. is the worst case!
Exercise: Why? How is this related to the Catalan numbers?

Here lies a hidden adversarial game!

Farm and sell (potentially losing out on price increases due to decreased supply) or hold on until the last minute and try to be the last seller (e.g. highest qty of unsold $PASTA before the price goes to zero)

Given an initial $PASTA distribution how long until there's only 1 holder who never transfers or zero holders? 

This question dictates how long until the end of the Fomo3d game

Why? One there are no transfers the pasta is worth 0 (c.f. Supreme 🪓)

Next suppose that $PASTA has 2n holders who own equal parts of the supply

Pair them into pairs (1, 2), ..., (2n-1, 2n) and have each send their share back and forth until the supply goes to zero

Then it takes ceil(n * (log(1.5e7/2n)/log(1.01)) steps to go to zero

Suppose there exists one $PASTA holder A_0 who holds the entire supply

If they play hot 🍠 and send the entire supply to another address A_1 who sends it to A_2, ... A_n until the supply is 0

What is n?

n = ceil(log(1.5e7)/log(1.01)) = 1661

@dankrad @hasufl @compoundfinance @AaveAave @opyn_ It is technically hard to compare the risk associated to predicates for slashing conditions to predicates for liquidation conditions that lead to an insurance payment, but a DeFi insurance payment is only as good as its ability to get executed by an L1 which is strictly weaker

@hasufl @dankrad @compoundfinance @AaveAave @opyn_ Err, insurance funds are stronger than no insurance funds, but they're not as strong as L1 guarantees which could include agreeing on a new fork and state (vs. an insurance payment)

@odtorson @joonian @BitMEX @MakerDAO Things in PoS/DeFi aren't _exactly_ the same as MBS

For instance, there isn't a notion of "AAA" loan in DeFi (except for @AaveAave's new loan type) --- instead 'AAA' is referring to borrower/validator quality directly based on their behaviors observed on-chain

@odtorson @joonian @RobinhoodApp You can read the section in the following way:
- Map our formalism, under some limits, to CLO/CDO pricing [equation 9]
- Assume that users are rational portfolio holders
- Prove that they update their portfolios exactly like CDO/CLO portfolio holders do [Claim 5]
@odtorson @joonian @RobinhoodApp https://t.co/e3Pkb1Tb56

@odtorson @joonian Section 4 focuses on mapping the valuation of staking derivatives to securities on bonds (e.g. akin to a CLO).

The notion of factor duration and factor convexity exists for CDOs. For instance, @RobinhoodApp has a really great description of these in CDO option-adjusted spreads

@odtorson @joonian @BitMEX @MakerDAO But I agree, we probably needed to dive into the negatives a little more. We spend much more time on that in Section 3 of the paper, where we map staking derivative valuations to those of other asset-backed securities

@odtorson @joonian We admittedly only weakly h/t the house of cards (e.g. principle agent issues) and do argue that the same issues will arise but in a different form

Amazing to find an explicit proof of an @ole_b_peters-style ergodicity transition

BUT: clear that numerical methods and simulation are key to quantitatively identifying the boundary between 'safe' and 'unsafe' regimes

Using these tools, we can hopefully avoid 2008! https://t.co/HmfxvoE6PO

As we venture into this new era of reinventions of finance's past, we need too objectively assess the risks in the systems being built.

Frameworks like ours provide quantitative guidance on investor ROI in the 'safe' regime, default risk in the 'unsafe' regime, and inequality

One particular usage of this (perhaps to combat @VitalikButerin's skepticism): If an on-chain derivative is the biggest market for borrowing a PoS coin, then you can avoid most of the staking and lending issues from my earlier paper!

https://t.co/MYg5LxkA4V

Why? Well-tuned derivatives allow small lenders/validators equal access to opportunities that big validators have.

At the same time, many of the risks of MBSs still linger and designing these systems in DeFi / PoS can be a tightrope that is hard to parametrize perfectly

This is similar to @ole_b_peters ergodic economics observations: Safe derivatives ensure that the wealth distribution is ergodic and samples non-concentrated portions of space whereas unsafe / no derivatives lead to a high-degree of concentration.

Not all derivatives are bad!

But slashing/liquidations are probabilistic — need to use much stronger and more recent (2017) probability results

We find a surprising phase transition: At high borrowing and slashing rates, income equality 𝙙𝙚𝙘𝙧𝙚𝙖𝙨𝙚𝙨!

∴ Derivatives can reduce inequality in PoS/DeFi! https://t.co/MYN8eVVkcy

Our paper extends @giuliacfanti's framework to add in slashing

Slashing adds complexity: Money supply can go to zero!

Pólya urns do not do this — need to generalize to Pólya Birth-Death processes (urn can go to zero)

Studied in the 70s by Athreya/Ney https://t.co/uq6Eg9eIHj

Common critique of PoS/DeFi staking: extreme concentration of wealth.

@giuliacfanti, et. al show that w/o monetary policy design, PoS concentrates

How? They map PoS to Pólya urns ('rich-getting-richer' processes)

But it misses one big thing for DeFi: slashing/liquidations

But on the other hand, MBSs are the reason for #bitcoin
and this result effectively confirms OG Bitcoiner beliefs that PoS is more or less the same as the existing financial system (from a payoff/security perspective)

Is that the end of the story? No!

https://t.co/cg2r9h3dDo

Analyzing sUSD is particularly prescient — incentivized @CurveFinance pool effectively forces sUSD to the stable region

When combined with SIP-015 from @kaiynne, it turns out that SNX/sUSD is the purest form of a decentralized MBS as the liquidations exactly match defaults

Other examples: 
- Transition is the boundary of the default phase transition that was numerically analyzed in @gauntletnetwork's market risk assessment of @compoundfinance 
- @CeloOrg / @terra_money usage of CFMMs to keep stable asset (algo. stablecoin) w/ bounded variance

In the 'safe' regime, we show that the payoffs of a staking derivative replicate an MBS!

Moreover, we show a 'recurrence' theorem that says that if a staking derivative is in the 'safe' regime, you can have the synthetic pegged to a collateral price.

This is Dai, sUSD! https://t.co/4KePtxeTT9

Synthetic assets have a boundary between 'safe' and 'unsafe' regimes

'Safe': φ takes an 'well-behaved' (e.g. Itô process) price process for the underlying collateral and prices the synthetic

'Unsafe': φ is singular and the synthetic price is uncoupled from collateral price

Analytic properties of φ — convexity, smoothness — control the security, fees, and income redistribution of a synthetic asset.

We illustrate how to construct φ for @compoundfinance, @synthetix_io, @terra_money, and more in the paper.

Does φ alone get you to MBSs? Not quite!

How do we construct a mathematical theory that can encapsulate @CeloOrg, @terra_money, @compoundfinance, @MakerDAO, @synthetix_io, and more?

We introduce the concept of a derivative pricing function φ which prices the synth. asset (e.g. cTokens, Dai, staking derivative)

One of the early hints of this equivalence was @delitzer's blog post that inspired the design of @compoundfinance v2 (as detailed by @rleshner)

We use probability and stochastic processes to formalize this connection

https://t.co/hB2wViWRj7

The post motivates and provides background for our paper which just hit arXiv

The following are equivalent as portfolios

❇️ PoS w/ derivatives
❇️ Leveraged DeFi
❇️ Mortgage-Backed Securities

https://t.co/5j5tSk7jPU

- Synthetic levered assets in PoS and DeFi are MBSs. 
- Improvements over meatspace/2008 MBS:
   - Used to reduce inequality 
   - Avoid lending competition in PoS
- Numerical, probabilistic methods are key to correct design of these systems

Lack of decay means that:

1. Run a bunch of nodes
2. Observe balances at time intervals T, ... ,T+I
3. Statistically infer payment senders and receivers with high probability

Fit the model w/ basic non-parametric models, run nodes, profit!

Attacks run on testnet and mainnet!

Precision-Recall curves have v. high autocorrelation: Waiting 64s is forever — the Lightning payment snapshots don't decorrelate for a long time.

Compare: decay in algo. trading is orders of magnitude faster (e.g. alpha signal decay very fast)

tl;dr: @Libra_'s ≋LBR is basically pricing borrowing/lending rates for users and association members. Fixing SDR weights is very 20th century Bretton Woods, but some of the automated lending mechanisms in DeFi could provide fairer 21st century market-driven mechanisms.

Does this idea have legs or are we stuck with a single entity choosing weights?

Nice thing about Libra's CFMM constraints: They're convex! 

Lots of ReLU constraints — and as @GuilleAngeris and I showed, you can construct curves that respect these.

P.S. @CeloOrg has a CFMM!

Idea 1: Use @BalancerLabs, which has a programmable AMM curve.

Unfortunately, Libra's risks don't vary geometrically w/ lending supply — can be 'sharp' default to 0 regime when redemption ≋LBR is banned/censored.

Math: sums of x^a y^b are bad at approximating max(ε, x^a y^b)

You could design an automated market maker that accounts for these risks in the following ways:

1. AMM curve change with FX prices
2. Fees change with prices
3. Map 'impermanence loss' to Basis + FX + Quanto and hedge it out

Does this look like existing AMMs? No!

≋LBR is tricky! 

Unlike Curve, which only has USD coins that have the same mean ($1), ≋LBR has other risks:

1. Basis risk — Can I redeem for fiat?
2. FX risk — EUR went from $1.50 to $1, take a loss
3. Quanto risk — Should I charge more interest paid in ≋LBR vs. USD?

With CFMMs like Curve, supply (lenders who want interest on stablecoins) and demand (people who borrow stablecoins for crypto) are algorithmically matched+priced implying rates and weights.

Can we just use the @CurveFinance curve, implemented in a @LibraDev Move contract? No!

Evidence: Early success of @CurveFinance — borrow and lend baskets of fiat/alg. stablecoins.

Each basket of stablecoins mints a synthetic asset — basically ≋LBR —  and the IR charged for borrowing this pool is like LIBOR

But there are no human weight choices here!

One of the main benefits of having a BFT database as the core of @Libra_ is that implementing SDR weights becomes a short smart contract.

Answer: It doesn't! In fact, the fixed weights, while they might temporarily placate governments, will likely cause headaches down the road.

Can we make this more fair and market-driven, avoiding the politics of weight selection?

Yes — by, surprisingly, turning to DeFi!

Why?

The SDR-esque construction in Libra defines [I chose random weights]

≋LBR = 0.5 * USD + 0.3 * GBP + 0.2 EUR

Redeeming USD for ≋LBR is 'safest' and will have the lowest rate, but the GBP rate should be 1.6x the USD rate.

Control of Weights = Control of LIBOR! https://t.co/FECn2cxNNP

Primary dealers — banks, custodians, payment processors — will need, at times, to borrow basket currencies against their ≋LBR positions to service customer liquidity demands.

LIBOR = IR that banks charge each other for borrowing from each other

∴ ≋LBR ~ LIBOR + Collateral

Why does the 'stablecoins replace eurodollars' narrative need something like LIBOR?

 @Libra_ users end up holding basis risk — they buy ≋LBR with local currency and subject to differing lock-up windows and liquidation conditions that depend on the currency they buy ≋LBR with https://t.co/UYoEdjy1ce

Americans referring to 'Eurodollars' usually mean rate spread (e.g. excess interest a foreigner pays for USD vs. a US national). 

And eurodollar futures are the most traded product on CME

(Note: @ChiangRei and I used to trade the Eurodollar curve)

More:
https://t.co/t716iTvD7a

First: What is 'Eurodollar'?

Eurodollars represent dollar deposits held in foreign banks. 

There are a number of reasons people outside of the US want dollars (e.g. to buy oil). 

Foreign banks charge extra interest for procuring & holding USD for you — an interest spread!

Thesis: Crypto needs LIBOR if it is going to be a Eurodollar substitute

Antithesis: People trust centralized lenders/exchanges with fiat backed stablecoins

Synthesis: @Libra_'s new ≋LBR design *is* LIBOR

But can they do better than copying IMF SDR weights? 

Yes! 👇🏾

A cool result from this: We show that LP returns are related to the Fenchel dual function of the bonding curve!

In particular, path independence — breaking splitting a trade into two trades is the same price — is actually *bad* for being a price oracle. 

We show that being path deficient — it is more expensive to split trades — makes it *easier* for arbitrageurs to...

Given the close ties between microeconomic trading and convex analysis, @GuilleAngeris and I looked into how convexity plays a starring role in all known CFMMs.

Convexity provides three things:
1. Easy to arbitrage
2. LP returns are computable
3. You _don't require path indep._

The natural mathematical framework to encapsulate all of the known generalizations is convex analysis.

Why? As we show in the paper, this is a necessary condition for no arbitrage in the n asset to m asset generalization of Uniswap

But what else do we learn from convexity?

Why do we need these generalizations?

1. Multiple components: ETFs have N assets you, in theory, should be able to trade any of the pairs of assets to arb the delta between an ETF and it's NAV

2. Bonding curves adjust for volatility: e.g. @CurveFinance and @ShellProtocol

So, you might ask: no-arbitrage seems to be fundamental — how do CFMMs guarantee that no-arb holds?

In our first paper, @GuilleAngeris, @_charlienoyes, @htkao, @ChiangRei, and I show that no-arb holds if Uniswap is being arb'd as a price oracle. This paper generalizes that!

3. Flash Loans: You can create/redeem ETF portfolios _as needed_ and fund them with a flash loan that only executes if the portfolio is profitable

This last condition is crucial and unique to cryptocurrencies: You can use halting/reversion of code to *enforce* no-arbitrage!

What are the advantages to doing this on-chain?

1. Arbitrary decimation: Don't need to redeem integer share quantities [no ILPs, no rounding errors!]

2. Underwriter fees are transparent: @UniswapExchange's sustainability fees are 100x smaller than Blackrock for the same service

First of all: Why are there so many different CFMM constructions?

IMO: CFMMs exist to automate ETF underwriting (e.g. @blackrock's ETF division):
- 'create' basket of synth. assets 
- 'redeem' same basket 

CFMM curve: redistributes rev. to traders, LPs, underwriters (devs!)

@nicksdjohnson @JeremyRubin @_prestwich @gakonst @hashbreaker I do agree that the 'buyer beware' aspect of a lot of these optimizations is hard to stomach for the average piece of code. But once you have 10s-100s of millions of USD running through this code, it becomes worth optimizing each numerical calculation, especially if it is...

@nicksdjohnson @JeremyRubin @_prestwich @gakonst @hashbreaker ... with precision. Simple example: I want to compute p(log2(x)) for some polynomial p [one might do this in a STARK]. The radix at which I take log2 depends on the degree of p + the coefficient of p. If I use an optimization that truncates, I might have 'extra roots' of p — bad!

@nicksdjohnson @JeremyRubin @_prestwich @gakonst @hashbreaker Suppose that I have a desire to evaluate a function h to a fixed point precision of 5ulps. If h(x) = f(g(x)), then it is possible for f to truncate precision in g. Since many of these optimizations involve choosing a radix (e.g. for log), the end user needs to be careful..
@nicksdjohnson @JeremyRubin @_prestwich @gakonst @hashbreaker I agree! I should have maybe stated, YMMV or "⚠️: not for all contracts / client code"

@nicksdjohnson @JeremyRubin @_prestwich @gakonst @hashbreaker For the record, I don't think the compiler should do it, but rather a vastly improved SafeMath library that provides hints to the compiler.

@nicksdjohnson @JeremyRubin @_prestwich @gakonst @hashbreaker Sometimes the context matters, though. If you're more worried about safety or log2 is nested within a delegated call, it might not make sense to unroll to `SHL`/`SHR`/`SAR` operations to the code that some of these bit twiddling optimizations would give you.

@zkproofs @badcryptobitch The issues that @izmeckler and @verbine point out are hidden in the definition of S+. The non-uniqueness is avoided by zeroing out certain singular values and the rank issues are handled by elision of singular values of 0. See https://t.co/BfEOUDiRK0 (sec: SVD)

@zkproofs @badcryptobitch Yeah, it’s a bit hard to write out on Twitter while on your phone, haha. But the tl;dr is the knowledge of the SVD of M2 gives you an inverse and you evaluate the inverse on O(rc) elements (where r is the number of rows, c is number of cols) to get M1 represented in M2’s ON basis

@zkproofs @badcryptobitch So if u1 is the first row vector of U, this implies that VS+ e_1 = M1(u1); since U is an orthonormal frame, evaluating M1 on each pair of frame vector (ui, vj) gives you perfect recovery

@zkproofs @badcryptobitch If you compute the Moore-Penrose pseudo-inverse of M2 you can query at points equal to the right singular vectors of M2, weighted by the singular values, to try to recover M1. If M2 = USV*, M2+ = VS+U* so y = M2(M1(x)) => VS+U*y = M1 x. Using the cols of U* and reducing works

@visavishesh Kakeya sets are sets that you can map a compact interval to (e.g. closed interval [0, 1]) and rotate it by 360° and still be inside the set. The Kakeya conjecture says that there exist measure zero Kakeya sets — which was proven. In finite fields, Dvir proved the opposite..

@daniel_bilar @BrendanEich I agree its possible these floor/ceiling arguments are correct in the infinite time limit, but the null hypothesis that we're in the event space conditioned on a floor/ceiling has not been refuted! And it is more likely, given existing data, we are closer to ergodic

@kevinsekniqi To an extent, manipulation makes it more likely to be ergodic, as maximal profit oracle manipulation involves symmetric price updates (e.g. go leverage long, drive oracle up, cash out long, drive price back to equilibrium). Once you have these, max entropy leads you to ergodicity

@kevinsekniqi A justified assumption, unlike:

P1: "X will never be <$Y"
P2: "Why?"
P1: "Belief in the EMH / halvening / ETH hard fork / IOTA sucks / ... " 

Also: Oh wait, the EMH assumes maxent so we're back to ergodicity on non-compact domains...

@kevinsekniqi Basically, I would need much more data to refute the existence of an ergodic process than I would to refute a floored/ceiling process with reflecting boundary conditions. The Skorokhod theorem is not your friend @kevinsekniqi  :)

@kevinsekniqi The measure, using the Cameron-Martin theorem, of the set of floored/ceiling processes is smaller than that of ergodic processes

https://t.co/M8l8naSufV

@ask_aristarchus Assuming *permanent* floors or ceilings as boundary conditions is far more unlikely than ergodicity in the sense that there are fewer stochastic processes with this property

@ZenoRogue @nicksdjohnson @_prestwich @sunnya97 Yes, but @nicksdjohnson's usage of "non-Euclidean" is ambiguous. Does he mean a positive curvature manifold embedded in R^n, like a sphere? Does he mean a hyperbolic space or a space of non-definite metric? That's all I really wanted to point out

@nicksdjohnson @_prestwich @sunnya97 N-dimensional Euclidean space is R^n (e.g. zero curvature), (N+M)-dimensional hyperbolic space is *non-Euclidean* R^{N,M}. If you took special relativity, normal space time is R^{3,1} and the “unit spheres” are the surfaces you can Lorentz transform on

@nicksdjohnson @_prestwich @sunnya97 What does “in a non-Euclidean space” mean? You need to specify a dim. In fact, if I were to take that pedantically, you actually mean the hyperbolic spaces R^{n,m} of dimension n + m and metric (dx_1)^2 + ... + (dx_n)^2 - (dx_n+1)^2 - ... - (dx_n+m)^2

@nicksdjohnson @_prestwich @sunnya97 No, if it is a sphere in R^n, it is an n-1 dimensional surface (e.g. smooth manifold). You have n degrees of freedom and one constraint x1^2 + ... + xn^2 = R^2 for a radius R > 0 sphere
@JeremyRubin f is in Omega(g) iff there exists C > 0 such that forall x in the domain of f, f(x) >= cg(x)
@JeremyRubin Won't look like that, you need to reinclude things via inclusion-exclusion: https://t.co/QSS1NoTmpe

@JeremyRubin You're conditioning on the prefix [1,2]. Given a set of marked prefixes (that's the 'k' in the above tweet) and a bound on prefix size (l == 2 for this prefix), you can get better estimates. Including [1,2] in the filter is key

@JeremyRubin I think you don't get any compression over Ω(N! log N) unless you add a constraint like, 'here are k prefixes with max cardinality < l'. Once you have that, you can compress this as a function of k and l. As stated, it seems like you need all possible prefixes

3. Inflation, inflation, inflation! 

If the revenue from the auction goes back to the network, this can have adverse effects on inflation and the monetary policy of the network has to accommodate for this. After all, this auction takes place every block!

2. Optimizing an auction over orderings (permutations) is actually more difficult than you think. Optimal auctions are actually NP-hard — the permutahedron is big, man! — so you have to use approximations. Moreover, the set of rational, honest strategies is waaaay bigger.

1. (ctd.) Currently: Ordering comes from popping txns off of a heap 

MEV Auction: 
a. Selector picks txns
b. Send them to sequencing auction
c. Auction winner send the network an ordering
d. Network collects fees
e. Txns executed in the winner's order.

This is a lot more work!

1. Latency: We will definitely slow down any blockchain by forcing tx fees / gas prices to not uniquely determine tx ordering. 

Since the selector/sequencer are separate agents, we add some communication between the two auctions ➡️ adds a lot of overhead (just ask BFT folks!)

After some long discussions with @brockjelmore, @p_e  and Lev Livnev, I came to the conclusion that there are four challenges that this auction faces:

1. Latency
2. Optimizing the auction
3. Effect on inflation
4. Only attacks one source of MEV

Let's look into these!

Why do this? Front-running involves reordering txns by bidding higher than others (unsealed bid auction) and sort of griefs the network. If instead you have to bid for the right to reorder txns, then the network can 'tax' front-running in a certain sense.

But are there pitfalls?

In this design, @karl_dot_tech, @jinglanW, et. al split this into an auction for selecting txns (e.g. a block producer chooses the top k txns by fee) and a second auction whose winner gets to choose the ordering of txns. The revenue from the auction is paid back to the network

The main idea here is that we can split transaction selection and sequencing into _two_ auctions. Right now, most blockchains have a single, unsealed auction in which users submit 'bids' via the transaction fees they send.

I was been looking forward to something like this ever since @hasufl rotated my framework around miner rewards and inflation to the MEV model. But it does seem to have some rough edges that need some theoretical work.

@gakonst Lyapunov exponents and large deviation functions only work when you have static operators
(10/n) A. Performing statistical tests to decide if your operator deviates from random will take too long to converge and you're likely to mutate the sampling process.

(9/n) Here is my logic for this: If you have Gap(A) = Omega(log N) and Var(A) ~ sqrt(N), then you converge to a fixed point time t(eps) = min(t : exp(-Gap(A) Var(A) t) < eps) which give t = Omega(1/sqrt(N)). We only cross to Omega(1/N) if a > 1/2. Why is Omega(1/sqrt(N)) bad?

(8/n) ... means that a simple spectral gap analysis (with geometric decay) will not work. Your fixed-point equilibrium seeking operator will depend on the number of participants. I posit that an efficient market that is bootstrappable must have the rate be Omega(N^a) for a > 1/2.

(7/n) ... generates A and dA. If you can say something meaningful about these generative models, then you might be able to actually construct some type of meaningful estimate. There is one caveat, however — these systems have a network effect and are usually growing, which...

(6/n) ... involves constructing an operator A, applying it to a market, deciding if it has a contraction property and if not, locally mutating it to A + dA. So the real question of, 'how long does bootstrapping  take?', really involves studying the sampling process that...

(5/n) ... which is measured in a (usually Sobolev) norm.  The only time that we get metric bounds comes from the usage of the Banach FPT, which bounds the time by a function of the spectral gap of a contraction operator (this include Markov operators). However, bootstrapping...

(4/n) ... that it takes to get to a Sobolev neighborhood of a Nash eq. However, most of the fixed point theorems (FPTs) used for the existence of equilibria, such as Brouwer's, Kakutani's, or Poincaré's FPT, are topological in nature and do not provide metric bound on time...

(3/n) But the process of bootstrapping, as @kevinsekniqi is getting at, is really a process of bounding the time that it takes to get to a neighborhood of a fixed point. This is one of the reasons that eps-Nash is more valuable than exact Nash — one implicitly bounds the time...

(2/n) ... which are pts that are left invariant by repeated application of an operator. Simpler eq. like Walras/A-D prove the existence of eq. by showing that 0 is a fixed point of the excess demand operator, which measures how many goods go unpriced for a given allocation.

@kevinsekniqi I meant liquidity for the derivative; in theory, if there enough rational arbitrageurs, then a fee rebate (relative to other alternatives) should be sufficient. But at bootstrapping, you're far from a Walras Eq., so..  memes? 🙃

@kevinsekniqi The first PoS chain to a) represent hash power derivatives and b) have ample liquidity would win because you would get a positive feedback loop between this chain and the parent PoW chain. There's some type of decay, in that liquidity could be fragmented, but I'd bet it's exp.

@recmo @ArthurB 4/n More formally, the causal inference used here assumes that you can show that A -> B by Pr(B|A) dominates Pr(B| ¬ A), but assumes that all parties can estimate A equally. Algorithmic Game Theory results suggest otherwise, hence why the causality can be flipped without bounds

@recmo @ArthurB 3/n ...then *maybe* we can state that the player can make any of the choices conditional on the simulation. But this article really shows the folly of estimating conditional expectations (and measures/σ-algebras) on events whose size estimation is computationally unbounded.

@recmo @ArthurB 2/n The philosophical view is just a way of answering the efficiency related questions of, "how do I construct the causal network?" and/or "measure whether these facts are efficiently representable?" by the human. For instance, if we assume they there exists a PPAD == P oracle...

@recmo @ArthurB 1/n Your best strategy is only known if you condition on the player's mechanism (e.g. maximum expected utility) and the verification of Omega's omnipotence (the player can deterministically & efficiently assess the claim that Omega understands humans perfectly).

@8bitbytebit @_charlienoyes @zhusu @maxcwolff @arjunblj The hard part for blockchains is that log(Var[arrival time]) ~ log(E[arrival time]), whereas for CPUs, log(Var[Time to next cycle]) << log(E[Time to next cycle]). You pay for this relatively large variance in errors on time-dependent estimates
@_charlienoyes @zhusu @8bitbytebit @maxcwolff @arjunblj Time-dependent volatility estimators are sensitive to the fastest observed frequency, which is clipped by on-chain mechanisms

@_charlienoyes @zhusu @8bitbytebit @maxcwolff @arjunblj There are also weird issues with on-chain models in that effects that occur when a market rapidly flips between backwardation and forwardation (contango) will be exacerbated due to block latency and the equivalent of Theta in Black-Scholes will be dramatically misestimated
